pages.subdeck: Farewell ... closing ceremony
pages.headline: Goodbye, greatest Games
pages.teaser: BRITAIN says farewell to London 2012 — with the best of British music, dance, humour and pyrotechnics
pages.byline: By EMILY NASH, RYAN SABEY, ALEX WEST and NEIL SYSON in the Olympic Stadium
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN said farewell to the roller coaster of London 2012 last night — with a dazzling closing ceremony that thrilled millions watching worldwide.

George Michael summed up the jubilant mood when he told the 80,000 Olympic Stadium crowd: “Britain, you’re the centre of the universe!”

It was certainly a send-off to remember — mixing the best of British music with dance, humour and spectacular pyrotechnics.

But it also ensured the athletes who made our Olympic Games such a sensation took centre stage.

As the party reached its climax a wave of sports stars, including Team GB’s gold-winning heroes Sir Chris Hoy, Jessica Ennis and Mo Farah, flooded into the Stadium. Sailing hero Ben Ainslie carried the Union Jack followed by athletes from every nation, flowing in single file through the audience.

The delighted athletes jogged, danced, jumped up on the speakers as rockers Elbow belted out the anthem One Day Like This.

Team Ghana did the conga. A French team member even performed a back flip.

Then the 10,490 sporting stars moved into eight “mosh pits” around a stage featuring a vast Union Jack graphic designed by artist Damien Hirst.

Footage of London 2012’s incredible highs and tear-jerking lows flashed up on a pyramid of 303 white boxes — one for each event.

The impressive scenes gave way for the final victory ceremony of the games as the men’s marathon winners took the podium.

Uganda’s Stephen Kiprotich was presented with his gold, Kenyans Abel Kirui and Wilson Kipsang got silver and bronze.

As the massive crowd cheered the 70,000 Games Maker volunteer workers were showered with petals — while drummers and a choir performed the Beatles classic Here Comes The Sun.

The excited athletes had been at fever pitch as they waited outside to make their grand entrance.

Many tweeted to say they could hear the music but could see nothing — and were desperate to get in.

Swimming star Rebecca Adlington posted: “Stood outside the stadium waiting to be let in... COME ONNNNNN!”

Team-mate Kate Haywood added: “Stood outside stadium — missing it all!” And hockey star Sally Walton added: “Share the party... let us in! Having a dance outside.”

The epic closing ceremony began with a journey through a normal working day in the life of London from dawn until sunset — featuring iconic landmarks Big Ben, The Gherkin and Tower Bridge.

Cars covered in newspaper cuttings drove around the stadium — each clipping featuring quotes from English literature classics.

From the top of Big Ben the figure of Winston Churchill emerged — played by actor Timothy Spall.

He quoted the famous lines from Shakespeare’s The Tempest that featured in the opening ceremony: “Be not afeard, the isle is full of noises’.

Then Churchill yelled: “Stop!” — and silence fell. He dramatically gestured to the Royal box — to announce the arrival of Prince Harry, representing the Queen — and Jacques Rogge, President of the International Olympic Committee.

Also in the Royal box were the Duchess of Cambridge, Princess Anne, Olympics boss Lord Coe and Culture Secretary Jeremy Hunt.

Next we had a dash of British humour as Del Boy and Rodney’s Reliant van exploded on stage.

Sir Michael Caine appeared on a giant screen in a scene from the movie The Italian Job — and his distinctive voice echoed around the stadium to start the countdown.

The vast crowd joined in, yelling: “Five, four, three, two, one.”

At which point Del’s motor burst into flame and Batman and Robin appeared out of the wreckage — a jokey reference to one of the most famous episodes from classic sitcom Only Fools And Horses.

Then the party really got under way with a flamboyant section of the show that celebrated the best of British music.

But even the best parties have to end. And finally, London Mayor Boris Johnson drew down the curtain on Britain’s greatest-ever sporting adventure.

He handed the Olympic flag to Mr Rogge, who passed it to Eduardo Paes, Mayor of 2016 host city Rio de Janeiro.

London 2012 maestro Lord Coe said: “On the first day of these games I said we were determined to do it right. I said that these Games would see the best of us.

“On this last day I can conclude with these words: When our time came — Britain we did it right. Thank you.”

After 16 days blazing in the arena, the flame was extinguished. But for everyone who shared the glory of London 2012, the memory will continue to burn bright.

e.nash@the-sun.co.uk



Music legends raise the roof as perfect mix wows

By OLIVER HARVEY, Chief Feature Writer

SO we all came together for one last hurrah.

The last, crazy disco at the end of the greatest party of our lives.

They were all there, dancing along with giddy delight beneath the still flaming Olympic cauldron — the greatest athletes of our age from 204 nations.

Dancing at our party — celebrating The Greatest Games — as millions joined in across the land.

None needed much coaxing to join the rapturous singalong to Monty Python’s Always Look On The Bright Side of Life. Britain has managed to capture the bright side of life and package it to the world for the past 17 days.

With it, we’ve found a surge of collective confidence.

Everything worked, everything went to plan — on and off the track. And this from a country, doubters told us, that was unable to fashion booze-ups in breweries.

Like the Games themselves, last night’s Symphony of British Music was a mix, the best of the old and the new. Elgar and the Coldstream Guards through The Who and Muse to Tinie Tempah and One Direction. Witty in places, cheesy in others. But brilliant.

Last night we showed another discipline we are world-beaters at — a damn good knees-up. And credit had to go to organisers Kim Gavin and Stephen Daldry.

All were transfixed as 10,000 lights transformed the set of the newsprint city into a luminous funfair. The spectacle was staged using 108 vehicles, including 50 scooters and ten black cabs.

As Team GB marched in, four-time gold medallist Ben Ainslie held aloft the Union Flag — a flag for too long hijacked by hate-mongers.

This glorious stadium was again a sea of red, white and blue, as it has been at every venue for every event.

The very British sound of Madness’s Our House and Blur’s Park Life — performed by the Household Division Ceremonial State Band — became singalongs.

The appearance of Del Boy and Rodney in fancy dress as Batman and Robin in the Trotters’ Reliant van was a masterstroke. It will have baffled many in the global audience, but is a cherished part of our popular culture.

Just as it had come to the Games, Girl Power came to the party last night. A sort of, “You’ll never guess who I had on top of my cab last night...” as the Spice Girls re-formed.

They belted out classics Spice Up Your Life and Wannabe, which inspired a whole generation. And this Olympics has certainly been a triumph for women. Saudi Arabia’s first female Olympian Wojdan Shahrkhani stepped nervously on to the judo mat after hardliners had warned she had “thrown away her place in the afterlife”. Her bravery transcends sport.

For those concerned that our rainbow nation was splitting at the seams following last summer’s riots, the spirit of the Games and last night’s show have been silencers.

Muse thrilled with their theatrical performance of the official Olympic song, Survival, while Elbow belted out anthems Open Arms and One Day Like This.

One Direction were cheered through What Makes You Beautiful and the Pet Shop Boys — as ever — could be relied on for a spectacular display as they performed West End Girls from bizarre rickshaws.

Madcap comic Russell Brand gave the crowd renditions of Pure Imagination and The Beatles’ I Am The Walrus. Fatboy Slim cranked out hits Right Here Right Now and The Rockafeller Skank, Jessie J sang Price Tag and Emeli Sande reminded us why she has exploded on to the scene with a moving cover of Professor Green’s Read All About It.

Carrying the torch for British rock, Brian May and Roger Taylor performed Queen classic Brighton Rock — while Kaiser Chiefs covered The Who’s Pinball Wizard.

Tinie Tempah’s Written In The Stars and Taio Cruz’s Dynamite brought things bang up to date.

A high point, though, was The Kinks’ Ray Davies singing Waterloo Sunset, with its lyrics: “As long as I gaze on Waterloo Sunset, I am in paradise.”

London has been a stunning backdrop, but these have been a British Games. Among the army of Games Makers in the stadium — the volunteers who worked to make it all work — was Terence Brady, from Weston-super-Mare, Somerset.

Born in St Kitts, the Caribbean, the 56-year-old said: “I wanted to give something back to this country. We needed something like the Olympics to bring us all together. Now we need to keep this alive.”

As a reporter, to experience the best of humanity’s drive and creativity — from Danny Boyle’s opening extravaganza to this wonderful closing party — has been thrilling.

The Fijian reporter next to me said: “It’s a great time to be British.”

The Olympic flame last night flickered and died. The spirit that Britain dazzled the world with doesn’t have to.

pages.headline: 65 medals, 114 heroes
pages.teaser: GREAT Britons show off their medals — as they celebrate our most successful Olympics in more than a century
pages.articlebody:
GREAT Britons show off their medals yesterday — as they celebrate our most successful Olympics in more than a century.

An astonishing 114 members of glorious Team GB won medals — just over one in five of the 541-strong squad.

Three gongs were added to our haul yesterday, making a magnificent final tally of 65 — with 29 golds, 17 silvers and 19 bronzes.

Anthony Joshua boxed his way to gold in the super heavyweight event after Fred Evans won silver in the welterweight category. Samantha Murray later added another silver in the modern pentathlon.

And last night Britain finished THIRD in the global medals table behind US and China, with our biggest takings since 1908.

British Olympic Association boss Andy Hunt hailed it the “greatest performance of our greatest team at the greatest Olympics ever”.

He added: “Combine that with the support of the British public and it’s been magical. It’s lifted the whole country, brought people together and it’s been a fantastic performance. I’m very proud of what we’ve done.”

Yesterday the Queen congratulated British and Commonwealth athletes, saying they had “captured the public’s imagination and earned their admiration”.

She added: “The outstanding performance of Team GB in achieving the greatest Olympic success since 1908, will, I am sure, have inspired a new generation of Olympians and reminded us all how sport unifies communities and nations. I congratulate, too, the organisers of the Games, as well as the thousands of volunteers who have epitomised the Olympic spirit through the warm welcome they have shown to the sporting teams and spectators from all around the world.”

The Queen and Prince Philip will hold a reception for Team GB at Buckingham Palace in October.

London Mayor Boris Johnson said yesterday’s final three medal wins brought “a fairy-tale end to the greatest Olympics ever staged”.

He added: “The Herculean efforts of our sports men and woman have truly scaled the heights, delivering a third place ranking for Team GB which we hardly dared to believe possible.

“Athletes from every competing nation deserve our collective praise in testimony to their staggering dedication and hard work, which has delivered a truly thrilling spectacle for billions of spectators around the globe.”

Perhaps the most memorable day of the Games was the gold rush of Super Saturday — when Mo Farah, Jessica Ennis and Greg Rutherford all grabbed gold medals within 45 minutes of each other.

They are now among those tipped to rake in thousands from book deals as experts predict huge demand for Olympic autobiographies.

HarperSport boss Rory Scarfe told The Bookseller trade magazine: “Mo Farah is very interesting — he’s got an amazing story.”

But it’s not just the star gold medal winners who are set to cash in. Up-and-coming star Adam Gemili — at the centre of the 4x100m relay blunder that cost his team a place in the final — is also in line for a big advance for his story.

Publisher Yellow Jersey has already signed up for a new autobiography of cycle hero Bradley Wiggins. Rower Greg Searle’s memoir If Not Now, When? is published by Pan Macmillan this month.

Victoria Pendleton’s autobiography Between the Lines is published next month by HarperSport.

Sainsbury’s head of books Phil Carroll said Olympic merchandise, including books, has been “selling well against forecast”.

Olympics memorabilia is also doing a roaring trade online. Items up for sale on the official London 2012 auction site included a pair of Tom Daley’s Speedos, signed by the bronze medal-winning diver.

Replica cycling jerseys signed by Bradley Wiggins and Sir Chris Hoy were also up for grabs.

Bids for the basketball used in the men’s final topped £3,000 yesterday.

The official results sheet from the men’s 4 x 100m relay final was on offer for bids of £4,500 or more.

Fans of Danny Boyle’s opening ceremony could snap up one of the maypoles used in the Green and Pleasant Land segment, with bids topping £200 last night.

Also available were costumes used in the ceremony, including the nurses’ outfits. All profits from the official auction site will be distributed to sporting bodies.

Meanwhile, on eBay sellers were offering “bottled Olympic air” and a tissue used to wipe a seat at the stadium.

j.mills@the-sun.co.uk



Boxer Joshua hits 29th gold

BOXER Anthony Joshua capped a magnificent Games for Team GB’s fighters by taking the super-heavyweight gold yesterday.

Big Josh — all 6ft 6in of him — beat defending champion Roberto Cammarelle of Italy on countback after a nailbiting draw.

Anthony, 22, of Finchley, North London, was three points behind going into the final round when he let fly with a flurry of punches.

With the final score 18-18, the 10,000 crowd at the ExCel arena erupted as the referee awarded it to the Brit.

But there was an agonising ten-minute wait after the Italians lodged a protest, which was rejected. Anthony said: “I am an Olympic champion now. This is a golden moment.”

His mother Yeta, who had watched his previous bouts on TV, was there — and he gave her his flowers from the podium.

Hopes of a second gold of the day were dashed as welterweight Fred Evans lost to Kazakhstan’s Serik Sapiyev.

But Evans, 21, of Cardiff, was thrilled with silver. He said: “It’s what I’ve waited a long time for.”



Shooter Sam in last silver

SAMANTHA Murray completed Britain’s amazing medal haul by clinching silver in the final event of the Games last night — the modern pentathlon.

Battling Samantha started the final event — the combined run and shoot — in Greenwich Park, South East London, in fourth place.

Competitors had three rounds of shooting, each followed by a 1,000m run.

And Samantha put in a strong last leg to finish second behind Lithuania’s Laura Asadauskaite.

The 22-year-old, of Preston, Lancs, had a miserable start in the fencing but put in a strong swim, finishing 200m in 2min 8.2s.

She put two fences down in the showjumping, which left her with much to do in the final test of the pentathlon, modelled on the skills of a 19th-century soldier.

Samantha said last night: “I had a lot to make up on the run. I’m just so pleased my legs kept running. Up the hills was so steep and I just kept working hard.”

She added: “Four years ago I started pentathlon. Since then I’ve come through the ranks, won some medals and made it to the Olympic Games.”

Great Britain’s Mhairi Spence, 26, the world champion, finished 21st after a tough showjumping round.



An apology from Moany Tony, The Sun's Olympic whinger

IN previous articles I may have given readers the impression that the Olympics were an endless, tedious waste of money.

It has been pointed out, and I now accept, that in fact the Games were a fabulous festival of sporting excellence enjoyed by billions around the globe and a dazzling showcase for modern Britain. I am happy to put the record straight.

pages.headline: We lit the flame and lit up the world
pages.teaser: LORD Coe proudly announced the closing of ‘a wonderful games in a wonderful city’
pages.articlebody:
LORD Coe proudly told billions watching the closing ceremony across the globe last night that the Games had “lit up the world”.

Speaking to the packed crowd in the stadium and the huge worldwide TV audience, the ex-Olympic champion and London 2012 boss added: “Britain, we did it right.”

He said: “Today sees the closing of a wonderful Games in a wonderful city.

“We lit the flame and lit up the world.

“For the third time in its history London was granted the trust of the Olympic movement and once again we have shown ourselves worthy of that trust. And for that I want to say thank you.”

Lord Coe went on: “Thank you to the people who built the stadiums, the people who created a new neighbourhood in an old city, the people who stood guard to keep us safe.

“Thank you to the London Organising team — to every one of you who worked so hard, and who turned the buildings into a theatre of sport and drama, and choreographed these Games — and to the International Olympic Committee which has been with us every step of the way.

“Thank you to the tens of thousands of volunteers who gave their time, boundless enthusiasm and goodwill — and who have the right to say: ‘I made London 2012’.

“And thank you to the people of this country. The British people got behind London’s bid and they got behind London’s Games.

“Our opening ceremony proclaimed that these would be a Games for everyone. At our closing ceremony, we can say that these were a Games by everyone.”

Lord Coe then looked back on the past two weeks saying: “London 2012 has played host to some incredible sport.

“To awe-inspiring feats that are the result of incredible dedication and skill by the world’s great sportsmen and women.

“To all the Olympians who came to London to compete — thank you.

“Those of us who came to watch witnessed moments of heroism and heartbreak that will live long in the memory.

“You have our admiration and our congratulations.” He added: “This may be the end of these two glorious weeks in London. But what we have begun will not stop now.

“The spirit of these Olympics will inspire a generation.

“We have seen in these days what tenacity can do, what ambition can do, what imagination can do. We know more now, as individuals and as a nation, just what we are capable of. And that knowledge will drive us on.”

Finally he told the watching world: “On the first day of these Games I said we were determined to do it right. I said that these Games would see the best of us.

“On this last day I can conclude with these words: When our time came — Britain, we did it right.”

Prince Harry, who represented the Queen at last night’s ceremony, said the Games had been “extraordinary”.

He added: “They will stay in the hearts and minds of people all over the world for a very long time to come. I congratulate all the athletes who have competed.

“They have shown us that there are few boundaries to human endeavour.” David Cameron said the Games had shown off a “new generation of heroes” who will inspire a generation of children to succeed.

The PM added: “This is just the start of the next chapter — where we build on the success of the Games to leave a lasting legacy in London and across the UK.”

And London Mayor Boris Johnson said: “London will cherish its Olympic legacy. I hope your memories of London’s Games last as long and burn as bright.”

Barack Obama last night led the world’s congratulations.

The US President rang Mr Cameron to heap praise on the “brilliant” Games as well as Team GB’s outstanding performance.

He also thanked Britain for the warm welcome the US team had received, along with his wife Michelle who went to the opening ceremony.

a.west@the-sun.co.uk



Sun's gong for unsung heroes

'A medal for every volunteer'

THE amazing army of Olympic helpers must be rewarded with a special medal, a Tory MP has urged.

More than 100,000 volunteers, troops, cops and paramedics toiled behind the scenes.

Soldiers, sailors, airmen, police and other emergency staff will get commemorative coins.

The 88,000 volunteers will only receive a silver spray-painted commemorative baton.

But Tory MP Tobias Ellwood said: “The Games couldn’t have happened without them. I propose an Olympics Community Service medal for making a significant contribution.”

David Cameron said: “As international charm offensives go, I don’t think I���ve ever seen anything like it.”



£11bn bill 'covered by 2020'

THE Olympics will have paid for itself by 2020 thanks to the massive investment it will attract to Britain, economists predict today.

The total bill will be a whopping £11billion, the Centre for Economics and Business Research says.

But the respected think-tank also estimates that television images of London 2012’s spectacular success will give an enormous boost to the nation’s reputation.

Coupled with the regeneration of London’s East End through legacy projects, the event is set to bring an extra £1.8billion a year into the UK by 2015.

pages.teaser: FAWLTY Towers star Cleese weds for the FOURTH time — to a woman 31 years younger
pages.articlebody:
COMEDY legend John Cleese has married for the FOURTH time — to a woman 31 years younger than him.

Cleese, 72, said the age difference between him and Jennifer Wade, 41, “never bothers us”.

He said: “I couldn’t imagine being with anyone but Jenny. And with my record, that’s a remarkable thing to say.” Jewellery designer Jennifer, from Bath, is his first British bride — after Americans Connie Booth, Barbara Trentham and Alyce Faye Eichelberger.

Cleese added: “I never felt there was anything wrong with the institution of marriage — it was my ability to choose the right person.” He wed Jennifer on Caribbean island Mustique. She said: “We’re kindred spirits. When people see us together, they immediately get it.” Cleese wrote sitcom Fawlty Towers with Connie, featuring the famous line: “Don’t mention the war.”

Splits from actress Barbara and psychotherapist Alyce Faye cost him more than £14million. Cleese performed a series of shows dubbed the Alimony Tour to help pay divorce bills.

Cleese’s Monty Python pal Terry Gilliam said last year: “If he marries again, he is stupid. Each time they get younger.”

pages.subdeck: Dream come true ... Mo Farah
pages.headline: Mo Farah: Look at all the pictures of me!
pages.teaser: THE double Olympic champion picks up copy of The Sun which features him on the front page, the back page and the inside pages after his historic feat
pages.articlebody:
MO Farah picked up my copy of The Sun and looked at the front page. Then the back page. Then the inside pages.

The double Olympic champion said: “I can’t believe this coverage. Look at all the pictures of me.”

When I pointed out his performance on Saturday night had dominated every single news outlet — papers, internet, radio and TV — it was clear the enormity of what he had achieved was yet to sink in.

Seven days after he became the first British man to win an Olympic distance title in the 10,000metres he pulled off one of the greatest achievements in UK athletics — adding the 5,000metre gold.

Mo said: “You have a dream of becoming Olympic champion in your career but to do it twice in your home city ... there are no words to describe that.

“Double Olympic champion. Who would have thought that?

“All the sacrifices have been worth it now but it’s been a lot of hard work and graft.”

Mo’s reaction as he took the 5,000metres gold — wide-eyed, arms outstretched and yelling with unrestrained delight — is one of the iconic photos of London 2012.

He said of that magical moment: “My first thought was, ‘I can’t believe I’ve done it again.’

“It was the best feeling by far a week earlier and I had done it again. I just thought, ‘Wow!’

“I remember driving to a British athletics league match in the car with friends on 6 July 2005 when London won the bid for the 2012 Games. We stopped at a petrol station and heard it on the radio.

“Back then I dreamed of taking part, not winning twice. But before I came out into the stadium for Saturday’s race I was very calm.

“It was like it was my moment, it was meant to be. It shows you can get there if you keep working and stick at it even when there are lows as well as highs.”

Mo’s wife Tania, who is expecting twins next month, and seven-year-old daughter Rhianna were in the Olympic Stadium to share Saturday’s triumph. He said: “After the victory ceremony I kept the medal in my pocket to show Tania.

“Rhianna was running round and round with it. I think she was more impressed at seeing Usain Bolt in the stadium, though!

“We have the same agent and Bolt gave her a hug and she took a picture of him. She was like, ‘Bolt, Bolt, Bolt’.

“I rang my mum. She had been so nervous she couldn’t watch the race on TV but she was so happy.

“I didn’t get back to the Athlete's Village until 3am. I got some food and then tried to go to bed but I couldn’t sleep.”

Mo, who also won gold at 5,000metres and silver at 10,000metres in the world athletics championships and took double gold at the European championships, is dedicating his Olympic gongs to his unborn twins.

He said: “When I saw the two medals this morning I thought, ‘That’s for the twins.’

“I didn’t want to have one twin have one medal and the other left out. That’s what drove me on.”

But by dedicating the golds to the babies, Mo is aware he may have to get Rhianna an Olympic medal of her own at Rio 2016.

He said: “Rhianna has got the World and European medals. Though I may have to get another Olympic gold for her now.”

Mo’s triumph makes him a member of an exclusive athletic club. In the past 40 years only three men have achieved the distance double at the same Olympics.

They are Lasse Viren in 1972 and 1976, Miruts Yifter in 1980 and Kenenisa Bekele, who Farah beat on Super Saturday, in Beijing four years ago.

Last year Mo aimed for the double at the World Championships and narrowly missed.

This time, with 80,000 people roaring him on in the Olympic Stadium and millions watching on TV, there was no stopping him. It was the reward for a journey which saw Mo travel from war-torn Somalia with his mother as an eight-year-old.

He arrived in Hounslow, West London, knowing only three English phrases. They were “Excuse me”, “Where is the toilet?” and not so helpfully, “C’mon then” — which was to get him into trouble with a playground bully.

It was also a reward for the personal sacrifices he, Tania and Rhianna have had to make. They include the difficult decision to uproot his family 18 months ago and move to Portland, Oregon, to work with coach Alberto Salazar.

He said: “When I moved to America people said, ‘Mo, you are a double European champion, why are you doing this?’ But I knew something had to change if that next step up was going to happen.

“I was coming sixth, seventh and if I hadn’t made that change I don’t think I would be here with these medals today.”

Despite being together in the US, 29-year-old Mo has had numerous enforced separations from his family because of training in Kenya, Albuquerque and the Pyrenees.

Then this year alone there have been competitions in Glasgow, Boston, Istanbul and Helsinki.

Mo said: “It hasn’t been easy at home and Tania and I haven’t seen a lot of each other. I was even in Kenya when Tania told me she was pregnant.

“It felt like it was a gamble, moving my daughter out of school, taking my wife and not knowing too much about Portland. All I knew was that it was good for training. But half the year I am away so you have that responsibility to make sure they are happy.

“So I’m glad Tania and Rhianna like it. The other real sacrifice has been not having any friends.

“It’s a pretty lonely event. I’ve got my training partner Galen Rupp, who got Olympic 10,000metre silver here, and running friends. But you tend to drift away from anyone else who is not into running.”

One thing Mo has found tough is leaving behind his beloved Arsenal. Pride of place on a wall of the dining room in his Portland home is a signed Arsenal shirt.

Next to it is a frame containing his European and World championship medals.

When I visited him in March he joked that there was a spare bit of wall for an Olympic gold medal. Now he has two.

He said: “There is a space, so yes I’ll now have to get a frame and hang the medals there.”

v.orvice@the-sun.co.uk



Girl twinners

MO’S success may prove to run in the family — after a scan showed his unborn twins have long legs ideal for pounding the track.

The double Olympic champ has pledged to give the girls — due next month — one of his golds each.

But asked if he wanted them to emulate his success, he said: “I hope so. Apparently they’ve got long legs. At the first scan, they’ve got long legs because their dad has long legs. That’s one thing for sure.”



Celebs salute champion with Mobot

MO Farah’s Mobot celebration has become a national craze - with fans and celebrities flooding Twitter with pictures of themselves recreating the iconic pose.

The trademark “M” move was invented by the double gold medal winner on James Corden panel show A League Of Their Own.

Boxing champ Amir Khan, 25, tweeted a snap of himself doing the Mobot last night, as did soccer star Robbie Savage, 37, and rugby player Mike Tindall, 33.

TV presenters, cops at the Olympic Park and Usain Bolt were among others who gave it a go.

pages.headline: My secret city style Ri-search
pages.teaser: RIHANNA has revealed she secretly loves to check out what ‘street style’ Brits are wearing
pages.articlebody:
RIHANNA has revealed she secretly wanders around London to check out what Brits are wearing – the clothes that have street cred.

The Bajan beauty, who is producing Sky Living series Styled To Rock, told how she loves the capital.

She said: “London has always been one of my favourite cities to come to.

“I always go out on the street walking around to see what the kids are doing. They always set the trends for the designers.

“I find that the kids in London have so much style, so much street style and so much talent. This show was a way for me to give these kids the opportunity to see how far they can go.”

The show, which launches tomorrow, will hunt for a new British designer who will create an outfit for Rihanna to wear at London’s Wireless Festival next July.

But the singer said her winner would have to be brave.

She said: “To be the winning designer, it’s going to take a lot of guts. It’s going to take a lot of confidence. It’s also going to take a lot of skill, and collaboration with the various clients.

THE Cameron and Clegg families will both jet off to Spain today for their annual holidays.

The PM and his deputy have both chosen the nation’s most popular summer vacation spot to put their feet up for the next two weeks, The Sun can reveal.

They will leave Foreign Secretary William Hague in charge of running the country.

Lib Dem chief Nick Clegg is returning to his usual holiday spot in central Spain, the small town of Olmedo, north of Madrid, where his wife Miriam González Durantez was born, along with their three sons.

“I don’t call it annual leave, I call it a holiday — and I’m looking forward to having one.”

Downing Street was keeping the precise location of his Mediterranean getaway secret last night in a bid to hold off swarms of foreign paparazzi that stalk him.

The Camerons will also spend a few days with friends on the North Cornwall coast to continue a family tradition.

Mr Cameron insisted he would be back in time for the opening ceremony of the Paralympic games on August 29.

He will be hoping to take his first uninterrupted two-week break abroad since coming to office in May 2010.

Last year, his two-week trip to Tuscany was interrupted by the London riots, which forced him to fly back.

pages.subdeck: Her opinion isn't grey ... Barbara Taylor Bradford
pages.headline: Why Lady Chatterley puts Fifty in the Shade
pages.teaser: BESTSELLING novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford reveals why she finds Fifty Shades of Grey a real turn-off
pages.articlebody:
EROTIC novel Fifty Shades Of Grey has captivated 5.3million readers with its scenes of S&M and bondage.

But not everyone has been wowed by E.L. James’s publishing sensation.

Here, bestselling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford tells us why she finds the book a real turn-off.

WHEN I first read Fifty Shades Of Grey, I realised the book had no plot — and was shallow, juvenile and mediocre.

It was badly written and could not hold a candle to erotic classics such as Lady Chatterley’s Lover by D.H. Lawrence, and Henry Miller’s Tropic Of Cancer.

To my mind, Fifty Shades is a modern fairytale, a young woman’s fantasy — and Christian Grey a somewhat “contrived” dreamboat of a man.

And I decided perhaps Christian was the real reason for the book’s huge success. Someone women could fantasise about.

The perfect lover — one that doesn’t exist in real life.

Thinking about it again, I have changed my mind.

Not about the merits of the book, which still stand — but about Christian Grey.

As far as I’m concerned, he is every woman’s nightmare — cold, detached, controlling, manipulative and genuinely selfish. It’s all about Christian and what he wants from Anastasia Steele for his own sexual pleasure. It’s not about Ana and her desires.

She is being used by him, not loved. And that’s a bit of a turn-off.

Anastasia is attracted to Christian because of his looks. He’s tall, dark and handsome. And a billionaire.

And so she goes along with his weird ideas about sex, and some of his sex toys. Although there were not too many ideas in these pages, which became dull.

Inevitably, the “sameness” of the sex scenes became even more boring to me, and to most of the women who visited my Facebook page in the past week.

I’ve had almost 18,000 hits since posting a review of the book, and most visitors agree the sex scenes are disappointing.

They have also pointed out there is not much S&M or “dark stuff” in Fifty Shades as has been suggested all along. That’s the reason there’s been so much fuss. Some people have suggested the book should be banned. What nonsense.

There’s nothing that bad in it that it should be removed from shelves.

Going back to Christian Grey, he is so controlling he becomes a pain. He tells Ana what to wear, what to do, how to run her life.

As for Anastasia, she seems weak-willed and old-fashioned. It’s unrealistic to think a young woman who is emancipated and has a job would put up with his dictatorial ways.

She would no doubt move on in today’s world.

TWO firefighters have been killed and two injured while tackling massive wildfires near the popular Spanish tourist resort of Alicante.

British holidaymakers are being urged to stay in touch with the Foreign Office as forest infernos also forced thousands of Canary Islands residents to flee.

Hundreds of people were evacuated from La Gomera by boat.

The fires on Tenerife and La Gomera triggered the evacuation of more than 4,000 residents and the cutting off of many roads as precautionary measures, the regional government said.

Yesterday afternoon eight villages on Tenerife and ten on La Gomera were emptied. The fires are also threatening some of Spain’s most treasured national parks.

A UK Foreign Office spokesman said: “We are aware of the reports, which we are monitoring closely and we are advising British nationals to stay in touch.”

Regional officials said there was evidence that the fire on La Gomera was started deliberately as it had two focal points two miles apart that began burning within a short time of each other.

A statement said firefighting crews working on the islands were “finding it difficult to limit the spread of fire”.

Garajonay National Park on La Gomera is a Unesco world heritage site, with prehistoric woodland dating back 11 million years, according to experts.

Aircraft that were previously dousing the fires when they broke out a week ago were sent away as it was thought the fire was under control but winds and high temperatures have rekindled the flames, an official said.

The island is 850 miles off the coast of the mainland, so it can take up to a day for firefighting planes to return after being sent back to Spain’s south-western tip.

A hot summer has followed a dry winter in Spain, with temperatures reaching 44C (111.2F) in southern areas in recent days. The state meteorological agency has warned of “a high risk of fires in the country”.

Regional governments reported ten wildfires raging across Spain yesterday.

Fires in Spain and other Mediterranean countries damage hundreds of thousands of acres every year.

GEORGE Michael's appearance at the Olympics has provoked a twitter storm - with hundreds questioning why he performed his new single at the event.

The closing ceremony was being used as a showcase of well-loved British music with stars belting out classic hits.

But 49-year-old George followed up singing Freedom '90 with his latest single White Light.

And by playing the new song, rather than another from his back catalogue he was met with outrage on social-networking sites.

Richard Bacon tweeted: "I'm calling for a judge led, full public inquiry into George Michael's second song-gate."

Hundreds more expressed surprise he performed the new tune - and the singer was soon trending on the site.

pages.subdeck: Feat ... London has learned to walk on two legs after his accident
pages.headline: Amazing two-legged dog learns to walk again after fall
pages.teaser: BRAVE pit bull had limbs removed after falling three stories through a window, but is now back on his feet
pages.articlebody:
A BRAVE dog has learned to walk on just TWO LEGS after having to have the other two amputated following a fall.

Pit bull puppy London shattered his front legs when he fell three floors from a window and crashed onto hard tarmac below.

He also suffered burns to his paws and stomach on the hot surface.

But the cute pooch didn't have his wounds tended to for a month - meaning his front legs had to be removed.

Vets decided to fit London with a specially made wheelchair, but before it was needed the incredible pup taught himself to walk with just two limbs.

Amanda Giese of animal rescue home Panda Paws, said: "When he fell he was pretty much stuck where he was until he eventually learned how to navigate around.

“He clearly had been left on hot concrete or pavement as the bottom of his paws were covered in burns.

“But as soon as I gave him treats, took him out onto the grass, he instantly lit up. He knew at that point there was a different journey for him - he wasn’t going back to a place where he was in pain.

“Radiographs revealed his front legs were severely fractured and shattered. He was left unable to walk but has adapted to having front legs that no longer support his body.

“He gets around by scooting his body using his hind legs and if he needs to steady himself he uses his face as a frontal tri-pod support.

“He plays, he’s happy, he enjoys rolling in the grass just as any able-body canine would on these hot summer days."

Amanda, who founded Pet Paws in Vancouver, Washington, said London will eventually be fitted with a wheelchair because his current condition is putting strain on his back.

He should then be able to go up for adoption to a very loving home once his recovery period is over.

London was named in honour of the Olympic Games for his bravery and perseverance.

image.caption: Feat ... London has learned to walk on two legs after his accident

pages.subdeck: Light up the sky ... fireworks blast out of the Olympic stadium last night
pages.headline: Record 26.3million watch London’s Olympic curtain call
pages.teaser: WITH peak audience of 26.3m, last night’s closing ceremony attracted nearly as many as Boyle’s spectacular opener
pages.articlebody:
WITH a peak audience of 26.3MILLION viewers, London 2012’s closing ceremony attracted nearly as many spectators as Danny Boyle’s spectacular opener — and broke audience records.

Last night’s event, created by artistic director Kim Gavin, was a musical celebration featuring performances by stars of British music – including Take That, One Direction, George Michael, Queen, Jessie J and a long-awaited Spice Girls reunion.

The promise of Scary, Sporty, Posh, Baby and Ginger together again would have boosted BBC1’s pulling power for the three-and-a-half-hour show.

So, too would have the realisation for many Brits that this was the last chance to experience a piece of the home Olympics that has been so successful.

While the opening ceremony attracted a peak audience of 26.9million, the closing ceremony broke audience records to become the most viewed closing ceremony in British history.

The previous record was Barcelona’s in 1992, watched by 11million Brits.

The sun set on London’s Olympic display with an impressive firework display and the cauldron’s flaming petals being separated and extinguished.

The high viewing numbers last night were consistent with the success throughout the Games, as 20million fans watched Usain Bolt sprint to 100m glory, and 17.1million cheered Mo Farah home in the 10,000m.

Tom Daley’s bronze medal success in the 10m platform final on Saturday night pulled in 15.9million.

BBC1 controller Danny Cohen said: “It has been an absolute privilege to broadcast the London 2012 Olympics.

“It’s been a phenomenal Games and Team GB’s amazing achievements have helped draw huge audiences.

He added: “We’ve had fantastic feedback about the quality of the BBC’s coverage and all the teams involved deserve huge thanks and praise.”

pages.subdeck: Quiz triumph ... Dawn Harkins
pages.headline: Millionaire contestant uses £75k win to find long-lost son
pages.teaser: MUM uses cash to fly to Aus for reunion after giving up child for adoption 45 years ago
pages.articlebody:
A MUM has been reunited with her long-lost son in Australia after 45 years thanks to a £75,000 jackpot on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?

Dawn Harkins, 61, went on the TV gameshow hoping to raise enough cash to see the child she gave up for adoption as a six week-old baby.

She went in the hot seat opposite host Christ Tarrant and then immediately booked her flight Down Under to meet son Glyn in Brisbane.

Dawn, who is still in Australia, said yesterday: “I never thought I’d see my son again so it’s amazing to actually be out here.

“No mum ever forgets their child and I’m so glad I got the chance to meet Glyn and to give him a great big hug.

“I might not have gone home a millionaire but this trip is worth more than that anyway. I feel like the richest woman in the world.”

Dawn was just 15 when she gave birth in a mother and baby home at a time when it was taboo to be a single young woman with an illegitimate child.

Her parents agreed her baby should be adopted and she only got to spend six weeks with him before he was taken from her.

Dawn, who runs a teashop in Anglesey, North Wales, went on to marry and have two more children but never forgot her first born.

Her daughter Samantha, 41, began searching for Glyn to help her mum come to terms with her past.

She tracked Glyn down last year through adoption forms and detective work and found he was living 10,000 miles away on the other side of the world.

He had been adopted by a family from Manchester and emigrated to Australia as a teenager.

Dawn, a retired factory machinist, said: “I can’t begin to tell you how I felt when Sami told me she’d track him down.

“When she told me she had found him, I just couldn’t believe it. It was just before my birthday and she said: “Happy Birthday Mum I’ve found him”.

Dawn had called her baby Keith but he was renamed Glyn by his adoptee family She added: “Keith was just six weeks old when he was taken.

“I was living in the mother and baby home when they told me he was going away.

“I had no say on it at the time — I was just 15 and in 1967 you didn’t have an option.

“I ran to find them taking my baby away. I asked if I could give him a kiss and that was the last I saw of him.

“My children have always known they had a brother and Samantha decided to track him down. It took three months but eventually she found him.

“I was worried that we might face rejection but, fortunately, he wanted to get to know us too.

“I spoke to him a lot on the telephone but I could never have afforded the flights to get there.

“But going on Millionaire made it possible for me to go down to Australia to see him for the first time since he was a six-week-old tot.” Dawn, a grandmother-of-six, flew to Australia with Samantha and son Brian, 40, and sobbed when she met Glyn and his family.

She said: “It’s incredible to meet them, it’s like having a whole new family who I never knew about.

“I love it out here in Australia and I’m looking forward to making plenty more trips over.

“The money I won has made all the difference to us.

“He’s had a very happy life and for that I’m very grateful. It was so nice giving him a big hug again.” Glyn is married to wife Alison and dad to daughters Jessica, 15, and Natalie, 14, and runs a flooring company in Brisbane.

He said: “It is fantastic to be with my mother after all those years. I’m so glad she got those questions right.”

pages.subdeck: Booze ... bears got through over 100 cans of beer
pages.headline: Boozed up bears sink over 100 beers after cabin break-in
pages.teaser: MOTHER and cubs got grizzly — after getting their claws into more than 100 cans of beer, according to reports in Norway
pages.articlebody:
A FAMILY of bears got grizzly - after getting their claws into more than 100 cans of beer, reports said.

The mother and her three clubs broke into a holiday cabin in Norway and cleaned it out of food and drink - including a stash of booze.

The cabin’s owner said there were over 100 cans of beer inside the hut at the time, but they vanished after the animals' rampage.

Even Borthen Nilsen said the alcohol was being stored in the hut in preparation for the autumn hunting season but had been taken by the family of beasts.

Even told how the bears had only left behind excrement, footprints and an awful stench after a night on the lash.

He said: "They had a hell of a party in there."

Even said the bears had also chomped their way through marshmallows, chocolate spread and honey.

He added: "The entire cabin was destroyed. The beds and all kitchen appliances, stove, oven and cupboards and shelves were all smashed to pieces.

"They have bitten into the cans and drunk the beer.

"It's almost like taken out of Goldilocks and the three bears."

The destruction at the family-owned hut in Jarfjord, Finnmarken, north Norway, was discovered by Even's mother and grandmother.

Even said he was worried the bears may return in search of more alcohol now they have got the taste for beer.

pages.subdeck: Is this what perfection looks like? ... cottage
pages.headline: Best of both worlds – is this Britain’s most perfect home?
pages.teaser: A DORSET cottage that boasts both countryside living and sea views, is described as ‘perfect’, and is on the market
pages.articlebody:
A GORGEOUS cottage that boasts both countryside living and sea views has been described as Britain’s most perfect property — and is now on the market.

The thatched roof, cultivated gardens and idyllic setting have combined to make this pretty-as-a-picture cottage worth a cool £3MILLION.

The house has four bedrooms — three with en suite bathrooms, a study, a large conservatory and cottage gardens to the front and back.

Number 26 Avon Run Road, perched on a cliff-top in Christchurch, Dorset enjoys magnificent views of the Solent and the Needles and has had the same owner for nearly 20 years.

Mum-of-two Sandy Hollowood is ready to hand over her coveted home now that her children have grown up and moved out.

She said: “All the family have grown up and moved on and it doesn’t make sense for me to be rattling around a four-bedroom house by myself.

Mrs Hollowood, 56, has previously rejected informal offers by wealthy people turning up at her front door.

But now is the right time for her to sell and she will use some of the sale money to fund trips to Australia to visit her son who is emigrating Down Under.

Her main concern for the property is that the buyer may demolish it and build a large modern home on the site.

She said: “It is a unique property. There used to be three thatched houses along this road but the other two have been pulled down.

“It is a beautiful country cottage in a beautiful seaside location – you really have the best of both worlds and I have been very lucky to have lived here for 19 years.

Stuart Mason, from Winkworth estate agents, said: “How often do you see what can only be described as one of the most attractive thatched cottages on a beach front with a fabulous sea view?

“It is a once in a life time opportunity.”

image.caption: Is this what perfection looks like? ... cottage

pages.subdeck: Mobot ... Mayor praised distance runner Farah
pages.headline: Bojo says Farah provided Mo-ment of Games with double-gold win
pages.teaser: VIDEO: LONDON Mayor performed the 'Mobot' in honour of the distance-runner after praising his gold medal wins in the
pages.articlebody:
BORIS Johnson hailed Mo Farah for providing his personal Games highlight - and even did a Mobot in the runner's honour.

The London Mayor was holding a press conference alongside Lord Coe and Jeremy Hunt when they were asked to perform Mo's signature celebration.

And while the Locog Chairman and Culture Secretary declined to take part in the gesture - Bojo jumped at the chance to show off the move.

Boris told reporters Farah's double-gold was "great."

"It was stunning to watch it because you felt that he was gaining speed because of the support of the crowd," he said.

Boris also expressed his “sadness” and “relief” that the London Olympics was over today as he claimed it had been “the greatest Games ever”.

“If you were to say to me that we have just held the greatest games ever in the greatest city on earth, I would say you are on the right track.

“It’s certainly true I did feel a momentary mad desire last night not to give Jacques Rogge that flag. I almost yanked it back.

“But I suppose there are two emotions - one is obviously some sadness that it is all over, because it’s been an amazing experience, but also a great relief because there is no doubt it has been a prodigious exertion by London and by Londoners."

pages.subdeck: Big problem ... child obesity is still on the increase
pages.headline: What the blazers? School uniforms get supersize as child obesity swells
pages.teaser: STORES say many primary pupils now need jumpers which fit grown men
pages.articlebody:
SCHOOL uniform stores have reported a rise in the number of pupils needing super-size clothes — with one 12-year-old boy needing a 60-INCH blazer.

Shops Uniformity Schoolwear and Rawcliffe’s said they have noticed the rise in child obesity reflected in demand for bigger clothes, which health campaigners have called "worrying".

As well as the 12-year-old boy, they said one 15-year-old had needed a 52in jumper and that primary school pupils regularly bought 40in jumpers, the equivalent of a grown man’s medium size.

School shirts now even have collar sizes up to 18.5in — a large size even for a grown man.

Brad Robertson, summer sales assistant at Rawcliffe’s, based in Leeds, West Yorks, said: “We are finding that kids that are starting school are taking bigger sizes.

“So four and five-year-olds will need sizes for five, six, seven or eight-year-olds.

“Over the past few years, bigger sizes have been selling out quicker than smaller sizes. It used to be the other way round.”

Brad added that there had also been a marked increase in the sales of special 'sturdy fit' trousers, which have a waistband twice as stretchy as normal trousers.

“They’re more generous on the waist but shorter in the leg, for kids who are short and round," he said.

The store now sells jumpers which go up to a 52in chest, whereas even the oldest pupils aged 18 would traditionally only wear 36 to 40in.

Varun Gandhi, manager at Uniformity, also based in Leeds, said he had ordered a 56in blazer for one teenager and sold a 52in blazer to a 14-year-old.

They have also been selling school shirts with collars up to 17in.

He said: “Two years ago the biggest we used to sell was a 15in."

The store supplies uniforms to students from around 50 schools around Leeds and Bradford.

According to NHS figures last year, Leeds had more obese youngsters than the national average, with a third of the city’s ten and 11-year-olds too heavy during the school year 2010-11, and 23 per cent of four and five-year-olds overweight.

pages.subdeck: Naked ambition ... girls take the plunge at mass skinny dip
pages.headline: Moon river
pages.teaser: REVELLERS stripped off at Oxford's Wilderness Festival to take part in a skinny dip of epic proportions for new nudist club Secret Swimmers
pages.articlebody:
HUNDREDS of people stripped off at Oxford Wilderness Festival this weekend in an attempt to unite the largest number of skinny-dippers across the world.

Babes and blokes in the buff cheered as fellow swimmers jumped into the icy waters at the Cornbury Park Estate, Oxfordshire.

The stunt was replicated in 25 countries across the world and launches the first 'Secret Swim' organised by the founders of Secret Cinema.

Those with a naked ambition are invited to meet every month to “Swim in the wildest places, rivers, streams, ponds, iced lakes, wild seas, reservoirs.”

The location is only revealed via a map sent to members of the community one week before the gathering.

And once the secret venue is out in the open, it’s time to bare all.

Festival goers preferring to keep their clothes on could watch from the side-lines or check out live music or films at the arty festival.

pages.subdeck: Badge of honour ... pals get a new tattoo for every Team GB medal won
pages.headline: Games fans mark Team GB medals with a tattoo tally chart
pages.teaser: FOUR pals from Llandudno get a new notch on their legs for every gold, silver and bronze we won at London 2012
pages.articlebody:
FOUR Olympic Games fans found a painful way to keep score of Team GB's medal tally during the tournament - by TATTOOING notches on their legs.

Tattoo shop owner Luke Williams, his colleague Blane Dickinson, apprentice Jamie Priestnall and their customer Gavin Hughes all had an INK-ling that our country’s finest would score well at London 2012.

So as a bet they decided to each have the Team GB logo tattooed on their legs and for each medal that we won, while the pals tattooed a black bar under the letters G, S or B.

Thanks to the record amount of medals that Team GB won, the group tattooed 29 golds, 17 silvers and 19 bronzes in their human tally chart.

Luke, owner of Top Notch Tattoos in Llandudno, North Wales, said: “It’s been amazing, the whole experience of watching the Olympics with family and friends.

“I’ve just got the last notches done. I really enjoyed the whole Games, watching it whenever I could with my family and friends.

“Just as we were finishing our first set of notches we found out that we’d won another silver, so we had to add another notch to the tally. And then they just kept on coming!"

The idea first came after Luke and his colleague Blaine, 39, their apprentice Jamie, 19, and customer Gavin, 29, were thinking up ideas about how they could make a lasting impression on the Olympics.

Luke, 27, said: “Since word got round it’s become a bit of a joke with our customers. People keep coming in asking if they can see the tattoos.”

Despite the pain, the lads are looking forward to having a permanent reminder of the Games in the future.

Luke said: “We won so many medals I thought we’d run out of room on my leg.

"We’re just happy that we’ll have a lasting memory of London 2012. It’s never going to happen here again in our lifetime - plus it’ll be something funny to show the grandkids.”

image.caption: Badge of honour ... pals get a new tattoo for every Team GB medal won

pages.subdeck: Direction ... could pop pin-up be inspiring mums' choices?
pages.headline: Harry new top name for baby boys, statistics show
pages.teaser: MUMS naming boys after Prince Harry and One Direction pin-up - while Amelia is the most common for baby girls
pages.byline: By HARRY HAWKINS and HARRY HAYDON
pages.articlebody:
AMELIA and Harry are the most popular names for babies, official new statistics show.

The upmarket monikers knocked previous favourites Oliver and Olivia into second place.

Harry, which means “home ruler’ has climbed five places in popularity since 2001, while Amelia, which means “work and effort’ leaped 31 places.

Baby experts said the trend for naming tots Harry was popular as the posh name is now “classless’, with famous Harry’s including Prince Harry, One Direction heartthrob Harry Styles and boy wizard Harry Potter.

Famous Amelias include X Factor star Amelia Lily, actress Amelia Bullmore and aviation pioneer Amelia Earhart. Similar name Amelie - a French version of the name - was number 54 in the top 100.

Boy’s name Jack which topped the list for 14 years to 2008 slid to third place, according to 2011 figures for England and Wales from the Office of National Statistics.The third favourite name for girls was Lily.

But there were regional variations with mums in Wales still preferring Oliver for boys and Lily for girls.

In the top ten girls names Ava and Isabella both climbed two places to replaced Evie and Chloe while Jacob replaced George in the top 10 for boys. But there were three different spellings for Mohammed in the top 100, which if added together would make it the third most popular boy’s name.

In total there were just six new girls names and five new boy’s names in the top 100, including Elijah, Tommy, Frankie, and Blake for boys and Bella, Elsie, Willow, Kayla, Francesca and Lydia for girls.

The fastest climbing name for girls was Eliza, which rose 31 places to 62 while Jenson gained 29 places to reach number 67 for boys.

But boy’s names Ben, Kyle and Cameron shows the biggest falls in popularity along with Caitlin, Katie and Keira for girls.

The Office of National Statistics said: “There is a great diversity of baby names.”

Netmums founder Siobhan Freegard said: “Both Harry and Amelia are posh names which have been embraced by the public. From Prince Harry to Harry Potter and Harry Styles, every mum has a favourite Harry. The name has become classless and suggests cheeky fun, so it’s perfectly suited to bouncing baby boys.

“Amelia, and Amelie which rose to number 54, are pretty, feminine names which have been climbing in popularity for some time. While Amelie was first popularised ten years ago by the French film of the same name. X Factor star Amelia Lily helped make the English version more widely known.

“Both are lovely choices and it’s interesting to see them overtake some of the more unusual celebrity-driven monikers. It seems mums are turning away from the unusual and back to the more traditional names, but with a twist.”

pages.subdeck: Family affair ... (l-r) son Luke, Jason, Julie and son Liam
pages.headline: Couple’s wedding a real Mickey Mouse affair
pages.teaser: MADCAP pair, congregation and even the vicar don Disney outfits as they renew their vows on their china anniversary
pages.articlebody:
THIS barmy couple celebrated 20 years of marriage by renewing their wedding vows — dressed as MICKEY and MINNIE MOUSE.

Julie Webb-Flint and her husband Jason, both 42, marked their china anniversary by dressing up in the life-size costumes of the characters to exchange fresh vows.

Amazingly, almost the entire wedding party donned similar Disney character outfits including Rev Richard Barron, who dressed as Friar Tuck from Robin Hood.

The couple’s sons Liam, 17, and Luke, 15, joined in by dressing up as Donald Duck and Goofy.

Guests opted for other characters, including Daisy Duck, Woody from Toy Story, Tweedle Dum and Tweedle Dee, Shrek and Fiona, Rapunzel, Cinderella and Snow White.

The congregation even danced to famous Disney songs at the ceremony at St Mary’s Church, in Greenhithe, Kent, on July 28.

The traditional wedding march was replaced with the Mickey Mouse Club House theme tune and the couple left the ceremony to Shrek finale track, I’m a Believer, by the Monkees, then A Spoonful Of Sugar from Mary Poppins.

Mother-of-two Julie, who had her honeymoon at Disney World, yesterday said: “It started off as a bit of a joke, but everyone loved it and it went on from there.

“We all had a great day. It was so relaxed and informal.

“The reverend said many things you never expect to hear in church – like, ‘You now may take off your heads’. It was really funny.”

Higher Level Teaching Assistant Julie and Jason, a builder, from Greenhithe, Kent, spent around £400 on costumes from Ebay for them and the boys.

The Disney-mad family love all the films, have been on a Disney-themed cruise and save up to go to Disney World in America every four years.

Jason said: “There has been too much doom and gloom in the world in recent years, so we just wanted a fun day.”

Rev Richard Barron said: “I thoroughly enjoyed it and they danced down the aisle to a Disney song after the wedding march. It really was a celebration of marriage.”

pages.subdeck: Boxer ... gold medallist Katie Taylor enjoys a knock-out check-in at Heathrow
pages.headline: That’s all folks — athletes given London farewell at Heathrow airport
pages.teaser: AROUND 6,000 sports stars greeted in style before flights home from Games
pages.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of Olympic athletes are heading out of Britain after an incredible 16 days of competition.

Heathrow airport has been given a Games makeover so sports stars are handed a final reminder of London before flying home.

A temporary terminal as big as three Olympic swimming pools has been adorned with plants, park benches as around 6,000 athletes check in.

Walls are decorated with images of the capital's skyline as well as pictures of traditional red phone boxes and a double-decker Routemaster bus.

There was even a bearskin guard stationed at ticket presentation as the travellers prepared to fly.

Athletes were invited to record their favourite memory of the Games and hang it on a tree which will be displayed at Heathrow.

A massive operation was launched to collect the huge haul of luggage from the athletes' village - with check-in facilities for bags moved to the Olympic Park.

Good-natured Games bosses even put signs to Rio 2016 at Stratford train station.

Athletes were clapped as they made their way to flights by a guard of honour made up of Heathrow volunteers.

BAA chief executive Colin Matthews said: “We want to continue the feel-good factor of the Games at the airport on our busiest day for departing athletes. I hope our Games terminal park will bring a smile to passengers’ faces and contribute to final happy memories of London.”

He went on: “Olympic Village check-in went according to plan yesterday with thousands of bags being processed at Heathrow overnight.

“Today’s departures present a fresh challenge with new facilities like the Games Terminal being used for the first time. We have been preparing for seven years to deliver a farewell of which Great Britain can be proud."

Bahamas gold medallist Chris Brown, said he loved the London Games.

“I have been tremendously well looked after here in London,” he said.

Proudly showing off his gold medal, he added: “These Games in London have been great. London has staged a fantastic Olympics.

“Everything has worked out well today and this special terminal is a bit of fun.”

Irish boxing gold medal-winner Katie Taylor said: "The atmosphere when I fought was tremendous. It’s been an incredible Games and I have been privileged to be part of it.

“It’s all going to be a bit mad when I get home I’m looking forward to celebrating."

pages.subdeck: Gesture ... G4S
pages.headline: G4S’ £2.5m to armed forces blasted
pages.teaser: GESTURE by hapless Olympic security firm branded too little too late by those angry that Our Boys were forced to fill gaps
pages.articlebody:
HAPLESS Olympics security firm G4S has sparked fury by giving the armed forces £2.5million as a “goodwill gesture” for their work on The Games.

The company said it had worked with the Ministry of Defence to come up with the figure for the cash — which will go to charity.

But the gesture was condemned as “deplorable” by former Labour deputy leader John Prescott.

Others said it was far too little, too late.

G4S boss Nick Buckles had a pay package TWO TIMES as big in 2011.

The security giant landed the £280million contract to provide security staff for the Olympics late last year.

But it expects to lose up to £50million after failing to find enough staff — and having to pick up the bill the government faces for calling up troops to man security gates.

Defence secretary Philip Hammond said the £2.5million donation went “some way” to recognising the burden placed on the armed forces.

He added: “This contribution from G4S is welcome news for the service welfare funds. And it will go some way to recognising the inconvenience and extra burden that this commitment has placed upon our forces and their families.”

The cash will go to army welfare and sporting funds, some of which have backed serving athletes such as rowing gold medallists Heather Stanning and Pete Reed.

pages.subdeck: Spice to see you together again ... (l-r) Victoria Beckham, Geri Halliwell, Emma Bunton, Mel C and Mel B
pages.headline: Girls Spice up the closing ceremony
pages.teaser: REUNITED girl group steal the show at the end of London 2012, turning up in black cabs and whipping fans - including Boris Johnson - into a frenzy
pages.articlebody:
THE Spice Girls stole the show at the closing ceremony of the London Olympics 2012 last night.

Reunited for the first time since 2007, the pop quintet arrived to a rapturous reception in black cabs.

As a swarm of taxis circuited the stadium, five cars made their way to the centre before Victoria Beckham, Mel C, Mel B, Emma Bunton and Geri Halliwell popped out.

They launched into their breakthrough hit Wannabe, but the highlight was their No1 1997 smash Spice Up Your Life.

Two unlikely people who were up on their feet dancing in the stands were PM David Cameron and London Mayor Boris Johnson.

The girls themselves jumped atop their respective cabs before being driven around the venue, entertaining the enthralled audience as they sped by.

The singers then regrouped in the middle for the end of the tune.

Emma looked on particularly good form, winning over a whole new generation of male admirers in a stunning pink dress.

Victoria also wowed in a tight black frock that showed off her legs, and even managed a little smile or two throughout the group’s short routine.

Mel B wore a figure-hugging bodysuit, Geri dazzled in a red number adorned with a Union Jack, while Mel C opted for a bright white baggy jumpsuit.

Following their triumphant return, Geri tweeted: “That was amazing!!!! Thank you all , we love you!!xx”

Victoria posted a backstage snap of the girls huddled together, writing: “We did it!! I love u girls so much!!!!! xxx vb”

It’s been reported last night’s gig will be the last time ever the Spice Girls will perform live as a quintet.

pages.articlebody:
WE don’t get many royals turning up at The Sun HQ, but next week the Prince Of Darkness is popping in to answer your questions.

Alice Cooper will be the latest star in our webchat hotseat — and few come bigger than the legendary US metal titan.

After 40-plus years in the music industry, Alice — born Vincent Furnier in 1948 — will doubtless keep fans glued to their screens as he reels off an endless catalogue of anecdotes.

And you can quiz him on all matters past, present and future on Tuesday at 4.30pm.

Last year saw him release his 19th solo studio album Welcome 2 My Nightmare — the long-awaited follow-up to his 1975 concept collection Welcome To My Nightmare.

He was also inducted into The Rock And Roll Hall Of Fame, alongside the original Alice Cooper band.

The singer adopted his band’s name and went solo in 1975, scoring his biggest hit in 1987 with Poison.

Despite his menacingly macabre on-stage persona, Detroit native Alice has become a hugely popular member of the heavy rock fraternity.

Click here to launch webchat player

Music isn’t his only form of employment either — he’s also a film actor, a restaurateur and a radio DJ.

Alice — who is a keen golfer — famously appeared as himself in classic comedy flick Wayne’s World and played Freddy Krueger’s father in the final Nightmare On Elm Street movie.

He also starred as King Herod in the West End cast recording of Jesus Christ Superstar in 1996.

The rocker has battled alcohol addiction in the past but beat his demons in the mid-Eighties and has stayed sober since.

At the height of his troubles in 1983, Alice’s despairing wife Sheryl filed for divorce — but they reconciled a year later.

The couple have been together since, celebrating their 36th wedding anniversary this year.

This summer, Alice supported Iron Maiden on their world tour and is headlining the Bloodstock festival in the UK this Sunday.

In October, he’s taking his terrifying Halloween Night Of Fear III tour across Britain, playing eight dates.

pages.subdeck: Bodes ill ... Macaulay Culkin looks gaunt and pale in New York in February
pages.headline: When we saw photos we thought, ‘Oh no, Macaulay is either dying of some disease or heavily into drugs’
pages.teaser: HOME Alone star’s dad and stepmum on his shock decline
pages.articlebody:
THE estranged dad of Macaulay Culkin last night spoke of his despair over his son’s alleged heroin addiction – and pleaded with him to get help.

Recent pictures of the Home Alone star clutching his stomach and apparently throwing up in the street have led to claims that Macaulay has a £3,800-a-month drug problem, an addiction to painkiller Oxycodone — and just SIX MONTHS to live.

Distraught Kit, 67, told The Sun: “I hope that he has the right people looking after him.”

The pensioner fell out with his son 15 years ago but he has followed the actor’s career and life from afar.

Now for the first time since then, he and partner Jeanette Krylowski — Macaulay’s stepmum — have spoken out in the hope that the actor reads it and seeks help.

And heartbroken Kit — who was recently just two days away from death himself before having life-saving heart surgery — is hoping that he will be reconciled with his son before it is too late.

Kit has seen the horrifying pictures of the actor — which show him looking skeletal and dishevelled — but is too traumatised to discuss them. Instead he leaves Jeanette to express his feelings.

Jeanette, 68, speaking from their home in Grants Pass, Oregon, with Kit by her side, said: “Oh, gosh. Kit has seen the photo. But he can’t talk about it.

“He just can’t, because it hurts him too much. Of course he’s worried, he’s incredibly concerned.

“When I saw the photos I thought, ‘Oh no, this is not good. Either he’s dying of some disease or he’s heavily into drugs.’”

Jeanette and Kit — who have been together for 17 years but have known each other for decades — had a growing suspicion about Macaulay’s alleged heroin abuse.

If the accusations are true, it would not be the first time the former child star has been involved with drugs.

In 2004, Macaulay was arrested for possession of marijuana and two controlled substances — Alprazolam and Clonazepam. He was given three one-year suspended jail terms.

Last night Jeanette said: “Now we’re hearing he is denying the allegations — but it certainly looks like he is on drugs. He looks awful.”

It was Kit who first put Macaulay on the road to fame.

The former actor started his son out on his career when he was only four and Macaulay was landing movie roles at eight. Kit quit his job to manage his son’s career.

Macaulay, now 31, became a household name because of his portrayal of Kevin McCallister in Home Alone and Home Alone 2: Lost In New York.

He went on to have roles in Richie Rich, Uncle Buck, My Girl, The Pagemaster and Party Monster — as well as his friend Michael Jackson’s music video Black Or White.

At the height of his fame he was regarded as the most successful child actor since Shirley Temple.

Macaulay was a millionaire by ten, thanks to the first Home Alone film.

He was paid £70,000 for that and £3million for the sequel, but he decided to quit acting aged 14.

The following year Kit left, Patricia filed for custody of Macaulay and his six siblings and a bitter public battle took place.

Eventually, the star had his parents legally blocked from controlling his £11million fortune — a move that estranged him for good from Kit.

He later said: “I’d made enough money by the time I was 12 to never have to work again.”

But, despite their troubled history, Kit would love to be reunited with his son. Jeanette said: “There will always be a sadness in Kit that I can’t fix. Our house is always open to Kit’s children. Kit still loves him and all of his family.

“I think if he ever got a letter from Mack or any of his kids, saying, ‘Gee Dad, I’d really like to see you’ or something, then he’d probably get back to them.”

Macaulay loves to write and in 2006 he penned a book called Junior, about a former child star who may be insane.

At first he claimed it was about him — then said it was not.

He said: “I disassociated myself from ‘Macaulay Culkin’ mentally. When I was 14 and I quit, I said, ‘I’m never doing that again.’ Say whatever you want about me, that I’m crazy, that I’m an alcoholic. Call me a drug addict. I don’t give a s*** any more.”

He is now a virtual recluse. Home for Macaulay is a £2million apartment in Manhattan. The actor has denied allegations it has been turned into his own “private drug den”.

The star has described his existence as a “simple, simple life” — walking the dog, feeding his fish, cleaning his home and cooking meals between his infrequent acting jobs — confessing that he is “not exactly the hardest-working actor”.

He said: “I could have just put up a big fortress around myself, bought a big chunk of land somewhere and just escaped.

“But I made a decision when I was 14 that I was going to live life.”

Kit simply wants to remember the blonde-haired little boy with a cheeky attitude.

He watches the child star’s movies over and over again.

Jeanette said: “The only place he sees Mack is on TV. But he watches the movies and he’s very quiet.

“I try not to bother him. But the funny thing is, I know he’s still very proud of Mack and his kids. We just hope there is a happy ending to all this.”

Macaulay has been through great sadness himself in recent times. His girlfriend of eight years, Black Swan actress Mila Kunis, dumped him in 2010 and recently started dating Hollywood hunk Ashton Kutcher.

But Kit and Jeanette believe it is the death of Macaulay’s sister Dakota in a car crash in 2008 which has ripped the family apart.

Jeanette added: “When Dakota died, I went into the room and I said, ‘Kit, I have something really, really bad to tell you. And he said, ‘I don’t want to know.’ That’s just his way of coping. I’ve never seen him cry. He just goes inside.”

Hermit Kit refuses to leave his home because he is still distraught about the breakdown of his family.

Jeanette revealed that it has changed his personality.

She said: “Kit is pretty sensitive. I was there during the custody battle. That tore his soul out.

“Kit is a lot different than the happy-go-lucky Kit that I knew in the Seventies. There’s a deep, deep hole that’s never going to be filled.”

Jeanette added: “We don’t live off a penny from Mack. We live off benefits.

“But we live simple. We’re happy.”

The facts on Macaulay Culkin

FIRST major film role was in Uncle Buck. Aged just nine, he starred alongside John Candy, who he would later be reacquainted with in Home Alone.

Previously he had roles in little-known American movies 1988’s Rocket Gibraltar and See You In The Morning in 1989.

His most famous film, 1990’s Home Alone, took £300million at the box office worldwide.

Macaulay has had 14 major film roles – the most recent was Sex And Breakfast in 2007. Macaulay has also appeared in US telly shows Will & Grace, Frasier and Robot Chicken.

In 1998, he married actress Rachel Miner, but the pair separated two years later and divorced in 2002.

In May 2002, Macaulay began dating Black Swan actress Mila Kunis, but the pair were to split in late 2010.

Culkin was arrested in September 2004 for the possession of marijuana, Alprazolam and Clonazepam. He eventually received three one-year suspended prison sentences.
