pages.headline: How to look great for a special date
pages.teaser: SUN fitness experts have a few tricks up their sleeves to help you look groomed to perfection in time for date night
pages.articlebody:
WHEN Hollywood actresses walk the red carpet, they tend to be honed and groomed to perfection.

Many A-listers work hard to stay in shape with gym visits. But they may also have the advantage of knowing a few insider last-minute diet and exercise tips when it comes to preparing for big events.

Well, why should you miss out? Sun fitness and nutrition experts Nicki Waterman and Amanda Ursell have a few tricks up their sleeves to help when you are getting ready for “date night”.

Today they reveal their guide to getting it right on the night with their pre-date preparation plan.

Diet

Here are Amanda’s Top Ten diet dos and don’ts to have you feeling your best, and her menu to prepare for a night out.

Don’t try to starve yourself: Fasting will leave you feeling light-headed, stressed and definitely not at your sparkling best by the time the evening comes.

Not only will you feel more like going to bed than going out but once you do hit the nightlife any alcohol you have will go straight to your head — which is not a great start to a date.

Have two eggs for breakfast: Eggs take up very little space in your stomach so they don’t cause bloating and they are extraordinarily filling.

A two-egg breakfast will keep you going until lunchtime without your stomach rumbling.

It seems to be a particular type of protein in eggs that has this satisfying effect on our bodies.

If you don’t like eggs, have a 40g bowl of Special K. It is slowly digested and not too bulky.

Stick with your normal coffee and tea intake over the day: The last thing you want is a cracking headache triggered by caffeine withdrawal on your big date.

However, swap cappuccinos and lattes for instant coffee or Americanos and a splash of milk — this helps to keep the calories down and, if you do have an intolerance to large amounts of milk, reduces the risk of bloating.

Avoid onions and pulses: These foods are classic for causing trapped wind, the last thing you need when trying to get into a favourite outfit. Swede is another wind-causing food.

This means that things like minestrone soup and baked beans are all off the menu for the day.

Stick with still drinks: You need to keep hydrated during the day to avoid added stress. Do so by sipping water and not having fizzy drinks, including sparkling water.

The bubbles in these drinks can extend your stomach and literally expand your waistband.

Have chamomile tea: This is famed for its calming properties. If you are feeling anxious about your date, you may swallow more air than usual over the course of the day, taking short sharp breaths rather than long slow ones.

Swallowing air has a similar effect to drinking fizzy drinks. Try having two to three mugs during the day to help soothe nerves.

Eat two squares of dark chocolate as your snack: Dark chocolate seems, from a piece of recent research, to be quite filling. Like eggs, it does not take up much space in your stomach or cause it to become distended after eating.

Other good choices include a handful of almonds or other salt-free nuts or a small banana.

Have a pre-date real Greek yogurt: It’s slightly higher in protein than other yogurts as well as being higher in fat. This means it is another good food for keeping hunger at bay while being nourishing and not causing bloating.

Try a peppermint tea: It’s traditionally been used to help calm the digestive system. Our small intestines and colon are especially prone to reacting to stress and can trigger bloating as a part of irritable bowel syndrome. Peppermint tea may help to steady things when getting ready for your date.

Slow down when you eat: Like being stressed and chewing gum, eating quickly causes you to swallow more air than usual, which can lead to your stomach and abdomen becoming bloated.

Try to chew for longer and to eat in a calm way rather than gulping food down on the go.

THIS menu assumes you will be eating a meal when you go out.

If you aren’t, swap the Greek yogurt for a plain chicken sandwich on white bread or a peanut butter sandwich on white bread. These will not cause you to bloat.

Breakfast: Two scrambled eggs made with a splash of milk, plus a slice of white toast. Tea or coffee or a glass of hot water with lemon.

Mid am: Mug of chamomile tea.

Lunch: A medium-sized avocado with two crispbreads.

Mid pm: Two squares of dark chocolate or a handful of nuts with a mug of peppermint tea.

Pre-date snack: Two tablespoons of Greek yogurt, a handful of nuts.

Workout

YOU don’t need any special equipment, just as long as you have a pillow and two half-litre bottles of water.

This workout is best done after a hot bath, when your muscles are warm and relaxed.

Aim to do two to three sets of 12 to 15 repetitions of each of the moves, right, then follow with some gentle stretches.

Please check with your doctor before starting any exercise programme.

1. TARGETS YOUR CHEST, SHOULDERS AND TRICEPS: These bent-knee press-ups will give you the toned, sculpted upper body you need to look great in sleeveless dresses.

Assume a press-up position with your hands slightly more than shoulder width apart, knees bent and legs crossed at the ankles. You can rest your knees on a rolled-up towel if you like. Bend your elbows until your chest comes close to the floor, keeping back straight. Hold for one count as you straighten arms and press up to starting position. Repeat.

2. TARGETS YOUR TUMMY AND WAIST: By tightening the abdominal and waist area, this exercise will ensure you maintain good posture. It will also remind you how to hold that tummy in!

Lie on the floor with arms extended at sides. Bend knees 90° but keep feet a few inches off the floor.

Place a folded pillow between knees and slowly rotate at the waist, dropping your legs to the left.

Touch left knee to floor, hold briefly, then bring legs back to centre and repeat on the other side. Keep abs tight, palms down and shoulder blades and mid-back glued to the floor at all times.

3. TARGETS POSTURE (to make you look taller and thinner): Not so much an exercise as something to remember. Keep spine in alignment, ears over shoulders, shoulders over hips, and knees over toes. Rest your weight on the balls of your feet for more graceful movement.

4. TARGETS YOUR BOTTOM AND THIGHS: These squat lifts will tighten, lift and shape your bottom, thighs and legs.

Stand with feet hip-width apart, toes pointing forward. Hold weights – or those bottles of water – with both hands on lower back.

Lower into squat, hips back, weight in heels, leaning forward with back flat, knees at 90°. Squeeze butt to stand. As legs straighten, extend right leg to side. Lower and repeat, then switch sides.

Stretches to finish

5. SHOULDERS AND CHEST: Clasp your hands behind your back. Lift your arms up slowly until you feel the stretch.

6. TRICEPS AND SHOULDERS: Gently pull your elbow behind your head. Then do the same with the other.

7. QUADRICEPS: Hold leg with opposite arm. Don’t lock knee of straight leg. Can also do it lying on stomach.

8. LOWER BACK: Lie on back, making sure that your lower back is flat on the ground. Pull your knees to your chest.

9. HAMSTRINGS: Sit on floor. Put one foot against opposite thigh of extended leg. Bend forward from the hip. Don’t bend neck.

pages.headline: Rosario Dawson: My mom taught me not to get pregnant when I was young
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD beauty, who is dating Danny Boyle, reveals what advice she took from her mother when she was young
pages.articlebody:
HOLLYWOOD star Rosario Dawson, 33, is the new woman in the life of film director Danny Boyle, hailed for his visionary opening ceremony at the London 2012 Olympics.

Rosario, co-starring with Bruce Willis in the gritty new suspense thriller Fire With Fire, is also known for her non-stop charity work, particularly for Aids and victims of domestic violence.

She reveals how her unusual mother inspired her.

“My mom Isabel was pregnant with me when she was just 16, and she taught me not to get pregnant when I was young.

She raised me talking to me about sex, maybe a little too early. But she made sure I had the choices she didn’t have. I wanted to go travelling and wanted to do this and that.

So I have avoided getting pregnant, and marriage. I am not against either. But my mom did not marry my biological dad, who I’ve never even met. She married Greg (Dawson) when I was a baby and I regarded him as my real dad. They had my brother, Clay, who is four years younger.

I was brought up in a rat-infested squat on the Lower East Side in New York.

I have asked since: “What in the world made them move two children into an abandoned building with no heat, no water and no electricity?”

The reason was that they could build their home around us, which was not something you could easily do in New York.

My mom learned how to do plumbing and they put in sewage lines. My dad learned how to do electrics and we had light. They also learned construction and replaced the slanted floors with a proper floor and put in windows. Suddenly, we had a home.

We were very loving and close and it was a fun way of growing up. It also gave me an awareness of life and death.

I knew about the risk of Aids, for example, from the age of about six. I am of the generation that grew up with Aids — just as the next generation had iPods and all they know is high-speed internet.

My mom was of the previous generation where if you had unprotected sex you could get pregnant. For me, unprotected sex could kill you.

I was in High School watching all these kids having unprotected sex and getting pregnant, with their reaction: “It’s totally fine — whatever.” My first film, Kids, when I was 15, was all about that very subject. I was hired for my looks (she is of Puerto Rican and Afro-Cuban descent) by director Larry Clark, who saw me outside our apartment.

There was also a strong theme about the risk of Aids in the film of the stage show Rent, when I played a character who was 18, HIV positive and addicted to heroin.

I am lucky, thanks to many warnings from my mom, that I avoided the dangers and just played it out in films!

I have not been shy of playing stronger women roles. Women are sexual and the characters that I have played are sexual.

I am not ashamed to do that. In Sin City, I played Gail who wears just tiny strips of leather, carries handcuffs and wears a mohawk hairstyle. I even had my hair cut for that.

My mom had shaved her hair into a mohawk at one point and shaved her head completely when she was 40 so I didn’t have hang-ups.

As for the film Alexander, which was trashed by the critics, I had this bedroom scene with Colin Farrell that people seem to remember. Sienna Miller told me that in London she read a review that said the only two good things in the film were my left breast and right breast.

I never had a burning desire to become an actress and timing has been very important.

Hollywood does not change and it never will for any reason other than money. No one is handing anything to Latinas, it’s just the population is changing in America and they want to see characters on screen with whom they can identify. That demand has given me opportunities. I love that, in acting, life is so unpredictable. I had started dating Jason Lewis (who played Smith Jerrod in TV series Sex And The City) before actually watching him in the show.

When I did watch it, I was surprised at how naked he was — and how often he had to be naked. I was watching with my mom, going: “Oh my gosh. Yes, that’s my boyfriend.” My mom, of course, was not in the least shocked.

She taught me to care about issues and people.

She would volunteer to work in crisis centres for women who had been beaten and abused. She also helped in a place called Housing Works, which was an organisation providing housing for families and homeless people living with Aids.

I would help her clear out houses in which people had died so we could bring in someone else to live in reasonable comfort.

My mom inspired me to think and work for other people.”

pages.headline: Here comes the bride-chilla
pages.teaser: FROM chilled brides to bossy friends and controlling mums, here’s who you may encounter
pages.articlebody:
WEDDING season is in full swing, which traditionally can mean tears and tantrums from nightmare brides.

But matrimony madness is increasingly claiming a whole new cast of “characters” to add to the tough-to-please, ferocious Bride-zillas.

Actress Jessica Biel last week admitted she’s in no hurry to start preparations for her ceremony. Consequently she’s been dubbed “Bride-chilla” as she insists she’s relaxed about the plans, saying: “I do feel like there is a lot of time and nothing needs to be rushed.”

Contrast that with Brad Pitt who has turned into a right “Groom-zilla” while planning his wedding to Angelina Jolie.

A source said: “Angelina isn’t so bothered – it’s Brad who is piling on the pressure. He wants everything to be absolutely perfect.”

Here, JENNY FRANCIS meets five people who are helping to populate a new wedding dictionary.

Bridesmaid-zilla

The bossy friend or sister

DEFINITION: A bridesmaid who controls the wedding as if it were her own, from choosing place settings to picking out the bridesmaids’ dresses and the venue.

Felicity Cross became a bridesmaid from hell when older sister Becky, 29, got engaged.

The 27-year-old who works in marketing made the bride, a communications consultant, change the colour of the bridesmaids’ dresses.

She also demanded that Becky run all music and food choices past her for approval, and even insisted that her big sister go on a strict pre-wedding diet.

Refusing to let Becky get married at her first choice of venue because it was “too similar” to where she wants to eventually get hitched, Felicity even picked out candlesticks for the tables for the forthcoming nuptials without consulting the bride.

Felicity, from Leeds, says: “When Becky announced in January that she and Tristan were finally tying the knot I had a feeling that it might cause some friction.

“Just because she was getting married first didn’t give her first rights over everything. I got my way and Becky chose a different venue, changed the bridesmaid dresses to cornflower blue and allowed me to make music choices.

“I tried on her wedding dress to prove she needed to slim down quicker, too.

“I just wanted to be involved in every area I could. But she flipped out when I ordered the candlesticks.

“And I have been trying my hardest to apologise for my bridesmaid-zilla ways.”

Becky says: “Felicity kept pushing to make my wedding hers and I had had enough.

“We’re still very close but I pity the man who ends up marrying her – or the bridesmaid who tries to take over her wedding.”

Bride-chilla

The laid-back bride

DEFINITION: A bride who is so relaxed about life she thinks her wedding breakfast will involve a bacon sarnie.

Bride-chilla Alison Jackson has taken a back seat when it comes to her wedding preparations since 26-year-old teacher Matt Carter proposed to her last December.

The 28-year-old, who works in sales, is so “whatever” about her engagement that she lies in bed on a Sunday morning while her fiancé, friends and family go to wedding fairs to research the big day.

The Essex bride-to-be says she can’t be bothered stressing about the colour scheme, whether to have pâté or soup for starters or what shoes the bridesmaids should wear for the event next February.

Instead she’s left the decisions up to everyone else and has even ordered the first wedding dress she spotted online.

Alison says: “I’ve always wanted to get married but never dreamt about the details.

“I haven’t got the patience for any indecision so the best solution is to leave it to everyone else.

“My bridesmaids helped Matt with the guest list, catering, colour scheme, their outfits, decorations, transport, flowers and a DJ.

“And Matt’s mum went with him to pick up items from wedding fairs. The most important thing to me is that I’m marrying the man I love. And while I know that, I’ll be a chilled-out bride.”

Matt says: “I’ve worked really hard on the wedding and it would have been nice to have more input from Alison.

“But I love her and would do anything to make sure she enjoys our big day.”

Big Time MOTB

The controlling mum

DEFINITION: A mother-of-the-bride who spends more on her outfit than the bride does on hers – and can’t help but make the plans for her daughter’s big day.

Retired Rosemary Sharpe was over the moon when she found out her only daughter was tying the knot.

Amy, 38, who works in marketing, is engaged to 37-year-old Corné du Rand. They are due to marry next month.

And desperate to make the celebrations perfect, Rosemary, 69, from Teddington, south-west London, took over the organisation of her daughter’s big day.

Picking the venue, choosing her outfit months before the bride, sorting the seating plans, making the bridesmaids’ jewellery and arranging the transport, it’s no surprise that Amy calls her mum her “free wedding planner”.

Rosemary says: “I could never be a mother-of-the-bride who leaves all the planning to her daughter and just shows up on the day. I’m a natural organiser and love to get involved.

“I love the Richmond Gate Hotel in Richmond-upon-Thames and dreamed of her getting married there, so I made enquiries.

“I also found the bridal shop where she got her dress. Although I’d bought my outfit months before Amy, I even began looking at a wedding dress for her.”

Amy says: “That’s why I call Mum my wedding planner.

“She’s always been very hands-on so I knew long before I got engaged that she’d want to be very involved.

“And I’ve learned to love it.”

Groom-zilla

Don’t worry, he’ll do it all

DEFINITION: A groom who takes over the wedding planning from his bride and will stop at nothing to make sure it’s all going his way.

When 27-year-old hairdresser Teegan agreed to marry Marcus Lovvell, also 27, little did she know she was about to wed the ultimate Groom-zilla.

Supermarket worker Marcus, from Irvine, North Ayrshire, embarked on a mission that saw him book the church, choose the bridesmaids and even hand-pick Teegan’s wedding dress.

He kept the majority of the details a secret from his wife-to-be until the day.

Marcus also chose a three-tiered wedding cake in the shape of a pair of lips and sent the wedding invitations out via text message.

Despite his wife-to-be’s pleas to get involved he was convinced it would be better if he sorted it himself. And she says, despite the stress of the lack of control, it was worth it on the day.

Teegan says: “He wouldn’t tell me the location, the food or any details as he wanted to do all the planning himself.

“I was worried not to be involved, especially when he wouldn’t even let me see the dress.

“I was shocked when it was red, but I loved the style.

“My friends and family thought I was mad for letting Marcus control the wedding, but that’s what I love about him, he’s a bit wacky.”

Marcus says: “It was stressful and I did turn into a groom-zilla but I wanted Teegan to enjoy the surprise and thought it would be better for me to sort the whole thing.

“And when we finally married we both breathed a sigh of relief and we enjoyed every minute.”

Groom raider

The mean man

DEFINITION: A groom too tight-fisted to splash out on a well-tailored suit and instead relies on a good bargain.

When Jack Rawles asked his waitress girlfriend Rachel Quinnell, 22, to marry him, he didn’t have the same big white wedding in mind as she had.

The 25-year-old project analyst from St Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex, kept his purse strings tightly pulled throughout the planning, even BANNING his wife from wedding shops and suggesting she shop for her dress on eBay.

Cancelling the professional decoration company Rachel booked in favour of cheap centrepieces found online, he also booked a local DJ instead of a band and roped in a pal to take the photos.

Perhaps most bravely, he insisted on a budget camping break instead of the dream five-star beach honeymoon his bride-to-be had hoped for.

Jack insists shopping for the best deal worked out fine.

He says: “A wedding is just one day, why spend tens of thousands?

It stressed me out when Rachel wanted to spend money on unnecessary things so I banned pricey items and fancy bridal boutiques.

“The day was perfect. Just because we borrowed chair covers and searched for bargains didn’t make it less special.”

The wedding cost £4,350 but Rachel says she would have spent at least £10k.

She adds: “I know he was being sensible but I did feel frustrated with him at times, and a bit cheated out of the whole wedding experience.

“But I had an amazing day in the end – so I guess it doesn’t always matter how much you spend.”

pages.teaser: CONTROVERSIAL comic Russell Brand on TV show about beating his addiction
pages.articlebody:
LESS than ten years ago Russell Brand was in the destructive grip of drug addiction.

His life was about scoring class A drugs at all costs.

The comedian was kicking about with a collection of acquaintances who were stuck in the vicious circle of illegal substance abuse funded by crime. Some were so badly sucked in they had lost limbs through the practice of their addiction.

He said: “Ten years ago, I couldn’t get enough — cannabis, booze, speed, acid, coke, crack, smack. I took drugs every single day.

“I remember being told that in six months I would end up dead, in prison or a lunatic asylum and thinking, ‘That sounds heavy.’ ”

But Russell is living proof that the downward spiral can be stopped through sheer determination combined with good emotional and professional support.

After Amy Winehouse died last year Russell was inspired to make a new hard-hitting documentary for the BBC about his road to recovery.

Last week her ex-husband Blake Fielder-Civil suffered multiple organ failure and is now in a medically induced coma after a huge drink and drug binge — bringing an added poignancy to the timing of our chat.

Add that to the recent story of junkie billionaire Hans Rausing — convicted of hoarding addict wife Eva’s dead body — and it backs up Brand’s belief that fame, money and class are no antidote to the condition of dependency.

Russell, 37, said: “It’s a subject that’s really close to me and Amy’s death can serve as a catalyst or serve as a symbol that people don’t have to die.

“Her death wasn’t inevitable — there was something that could have been done. I know that from my own experience. There are millions like her who have the opportunity to get clean. I wanted to make that film and work with Comic Relief so people could get access to the information on how to do it.

“I’ve met people both in addiction and recovery from all sorts of backgrounds and it’s no discriminator.

“It’s more apparent where there is less money because the criminal part of it is more evident, but the Rausing example goes to show that the desperation drugs induce in people who suffer from from addiction goes across the board.”

In the documentary, Russell Brand: From Addiction To Recovery, there is harrowing footage of him smoking heroin in his younger years.

The comic is almost unrecognisable to the man sitting before me in the salubrious surroundings of London’s Savoy Hotel. The footage shows him hunched on the floor of a grotty flat, barefoot and lost in the warm comfort of another hit of smack.

Now we are sat in the decadent five-star venue which used to play host to one of the most notorious British hellraising actors of all-time — Richard Harris. He was a man who would have admired Russell’s dramatic and hedonistic rise to fame during his own booze-fuelled heyday, but who died an alcoholic.

Both are effervescent, lively characters with an eye for the ladies.

But Russell is a very different man now, and his determination to tackle the thorny issue of addiction — an illness, not a crime in his book — is stoking the fire in his belly.

He explained: “It is a film about taking drugs and getting off drugs. Nowadays I don’t drink or take drugs.”

His beloved mum, Barbara Brand, opens up about her son’s dark years in the BBC3 film, to be shown on Thursday at 9pm. He asks what her recollections of the time were and Barbara, 65, said: “You were helpless. You looked so ill, skinny, not particularly clean, had no pride in your appearance or how you lived. It’s heartbreaking as a mum when you have brought an innocent beautiful little child into the world and to see that happen.”

But Russell has turned his life around spectacularly — with help from some strong characters.

His agent John Noel forced him to visit Focus 12 residential rehab in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk.

That was the start. Normally this is where a journalist would write, ‘He hasn’t looked back’. But Russell looks back every day to remind himself how worthwhile the effort has been.

He said: “I got clean at the age of 27, the age Amy was when she died.

“Amy’s death was a paradoxical unsurprising shock. I felt like I could have done something to help — to give her the chance I had. That’s why I made this film — to have a sympathetic look at alcoholism and addiction, a condition that the World Health Organisation regards as a disorder.

“Drugs and alcoholism are much misunderstood in our country — by users, non-users and the Government.

“We need to start regarding addiction in all its forms as a health issue as opposed to a criminal and judicial issue.

“It don’t make no difference to me — the money, the fame, the power, the sex, the women — any of it. I’d rather be a drug addict.

“If I didn’t have my programme I would be a drug addict today.

“I loved Amy on the basis that I thought she was really, really brilliant. I recognised that this person has got it, she has got this thing. She is not happy, she is on edge.

“She drank this glass of champagne and threw it over her shoulder once.

“I said, ‘What are you doing that for?’ She said. ‘I was doing it to impress you.’ I said, ‘Well... don’t’, then she started flicking lit cigarettes around the room.

“That’s when I got the sense of the ticking clock and spoke to other people, ‘Hey, we need to do something.’ ”

When he gets excited Russell speaks with the rhythm of a sewing machine at full steam, with a staccato beat to his softly spoken and measured statements.

He continued: “When she died, it was this feeling of, ‘Agh, I knew that was going to happen.’ And I had this flickering sense that I should have done something about that.

“I feel a bit guilty that there was nothing I did. Whatever anyone could have done for Amy, now one thing is for sure, no one can do anything — she’s dead.

“There are loads of people who are going to die if they don’t stop taking drugs and drinking. It ain’t necessary — it’s difficult for the individual, it’s difficult for the family and it’s detrimental to society and it’s unnecessary because there is a solution.

“For me it’s vital that more addicts get the relevant information, into recovery, change their lives and become drug-free. Amy’s death is tragic, but if we use it as an opportunity to review the way we treat addicts and addiction and alcoholism in this country then it hasn’t been in vain. So her death is sad, but it might not feel so pointless.”

The documentary brings some really interesting information to light.

More than 80 per cent of the British prison population are addicts or have some sort of substance abuse issue — but only one in ten gets any treatment other than methadone to break their habit.

A scheme called RAPt — Rehabilitation of Addicted Prisoners — at a prison in north London, is now proven to work.

If there was more Government funding available, it could be spread out across the country. Russell visits another initiative in Brighton where ex-addicts support each other to re-engage with the community. The local police now estimate that for every one pound spent on rehab programmes, the area benefits from £3 less lost to crime. It’s a dividend that makes rehab worthwhile.

Russell said: “I am into this long term. If I can quote from Rocky IV, which I find myself doing more often than I would like, if I can change, then you can change and the whole damn world can change.”

One thing Russell does not back is the Department of Health’s methadone programme, which he believes is as worthwhile as “re-arranging the furniture on the Titanic. It doesn’t work. Drug addicts are addicted to drugs, so don’t give them more paid for by the country. Even now if I take tin foil out for a legit reason, I still get that feeling of what it’s like to chase heroin and what the smell is like when it burns. It has to be complete abstinence.”

Alcohol is as important to the documentary, and something he had as many problems with in his twenties.

“It was alcohol that killed Amy in the end. Chip Somers, the head of Focus 12, really believes that, in the next five years, we will see a lot more trouble coming from alcohol.

“It is sanctioned and accepted but it’s easy to forget it is lethal.

“It destroys lives and has a terrible cultural impact. But alcohol is only really dangerous to alcoholics as drugs are dangerous to drug addicts.

“It’s about having joined-up information available to everyone about the dangers of illegal and legal drugs.

“If you know someone who has a problem with alcohol and drugs, direct them towards abstinence-based recovery because it works. There is a solution.

“There are plans with Comic Relief to launch a concert with some big names involved, so we have a lot planned to keep this going.”

As we leave the hotel, Hollywood star Arnold Schwarzenegger walks through the lobby with a stunning woman on his arm. He extends a nod of recognition to Russell.

Arnie was not in Rocky IV, but acknowledgement from The Terminator in the context of our chat, seems like an appropriate pay-off to our evening.

Highs and lows

1975: Russell is born in Grays, Essex, on June 4.

1990: Makes acting debut, playing Fat Sam in a school production of Bugsy Malone.

1995: Given a place at the Drama Centre London, but expelled during his final year.

2000: Begins to enjoy success in stand-up comedy, but struggles with drug and alcohol problems.

2001: Sacked from presenting job on MTV for coming to work dressed as Osama bin Laden the day after World Trade Center attacks.

2002: Spends 12 weeks being treated for heroin addiction in UK rehab centre.

2004: Gets big TV break hosting Big Brother’s Big Mouth and develops a reputation as a ladies’ man by bedding famous beauties including Kate Moss.

2005: Treated for sex addiction in a specialist US clinic.

2007: First film part, as Flash Harry in Brit flick St Trinian’s.

2008: He lands Hollywood roles, playing Aldous Snow in Forgetting Sarah Marshall.

Russell and Jonathan Ross spark fury with a foul-mouthed phone call to Fawlty Towers actor Andrew Sachs during Brand’s Radio 2 show. Russell quits and Jonathan is suspended.

2009: Russell meets US singer Katy Perry while hosting the MTV Video Music Awards, and proposes in December.

2010: He enjoys more big-screen success, returning to the role of Aldous Snow in Get Him To The Greek. Weds Katy in lavish ceremony in northern India in October.

2011: Files for divorce after just 14 months of marriage.

2012: Returns to stand-up with new TV show Brand X.

pages.teaser: STARS including Victoria Beckham wearing the latest maxi pencil skirt
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN’S economy could be about to plunge even further — as hemlines hit their lowest level since the Great Depression.

Stars including Victoria Beckham, singer Rita Ora and celeb stylist Rachel Zoe have been spotted wearing the latest maxi pencil skirt with a 33in hemline.

But in the boom years of the 1990s, Posh led the trend in thigh-high minis.

The theory that skirt lengths predict economic trends better even than stock exchanges dates back to 1926 — when they heralded a worldwide slump from 1929 to 1932.

The last time long skirts were in fashion was the recession of the early ’90s when hems dipped to 30in. The maxi pencil has been introduced for autumn and winter collections.

Though designer versions cost up to a stinging £595, high street stores such as River Island, Reiss and Mango are selling versions from £25.

Jo Hooper, of John Lewis, said: “We’ve noticed hemlines are getting longer for the coming season. They have the tendency to reflect the state of the economy.”

pages.articlebody:
A VENGEFUL husband burned £5,000 worth of his wife’s designer gear after she married her Gambian lover.

Darrell Plews, 44, piled bags, shoes and clothes on the patio.

He then torched the lot. Plews had tried to win back estranged Michelle after she went on holiday to Gambia without him, met a new man and asked for a divorce.

She rejected his pleas to try again and he was given a restraining order. The dad of two flew into a rage after hearing she went back to Gambia to marry. She was still wed to Plews, of Wakefield, but did not break Gambian laws.

His lawyer Richard Canning told Leeds Crown Court: “He finds it difficult not to see himself as the victim.”

Shop fitter Plews, now divorced, admitted arson and theft. He was jailed for 12 months, suspended for two years, and ordered to pay compensation to Michelle, 35.

He said later: “I burned her wedding dress first. There was also stuff by Gucci, Jimmy Choo, Vivienne Westwood — 50 handbags and 100 pairs of shoes. It helped my anger.”

pages.subdeck: Unamused ... by annoying emails
pages.headline: OMG – are your emails irritating?
pages.teaser: WE have become a very friendly nation but it can all be very insincere — and even rather annoying at times
pages.articlebody:
WE have become a very friendly nation but it can all be very insincere — and even rather annoying.

Informality is bad manners and a business email should be structured in the same way you would a written letter.

Here are the email irritants that drive professionals mad — and why they are so aggravating:

OMG/LOL: Fifty per cent find these abbreviations, as well as phrases such as “totes amaze”, grating, the poll found.

It’s totes not acceptable because a lot of people won’t understand you, and it's too friendly. You’re at work — you should sound professional.

SMILEY FACES: 44 per cent say that they are irritating and unprofessional.

Smiley faces are a bit 1999. One or two occasionally to people you know very well are fine, but not in workplace emails. It’s over-familiar and a tad childish.

SPELLING OR GRAMMATICAL ERRORS: Two-thirds say they lose faith in the sender when they spot these.

When you receive something riddled with mistakes it is completely unforgivable. It looks like you haven’t made an effort and that reflects very badly. Who wants to do business with someone who’s lazy?

GOING AWOL: 58 per cent say they will not do business with people who go away without leaving an “out of office” message.

My personal bugbear with these messages is, “I will be away until Tuesday”. What Tuesday? They should be specific. Put: “I will be away until Tuesday the ?? of whatever”. And you should leave a contact number of a colleague for urgent inquiries.

KISSES: XXXs are loathed by a huge 66 per cent. After all, we are still British, and we don’t like these overt displays of affection.

TERMS OF ENDEARMENT: “Honey”, “dear” and so on annoy 54 per cent of us.

They are not appropriate and can come across as patronising.

I work in the media and everyone is “darling” — but that’s fine because nobody can remember anyone’s name.

CHEESINESS: Corny lines such as “Happy Friday” annoy 28 per cent.

Again, it’s thoughtless and unprofessional — these people are not your friends, they are your clients.

pages.headline: I heard a guy called Tony Blair was PM – but I don’t remember him
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-THREE Kay Delaney, who fell and hit her head last year, woke up back in 1990 with 20yrs of memories erased
pages.byline: By EMMA LITTLE and ELLIE ROSS
pages.articlebody:
KAY DELANEY fell and hit her head last year and woke up back in 1990 – convinced that Margaret Thatcher was PM.

The EastEnders addict was also eager to see what the newcomer Mitchell brothers would get up to in Walford, and insisted the web was something to do with spiders.

With 20 years of memories erased by amnesia she also thought her late parents were still thriving — and that her grown-up children Kenny, 27, Sandy, 23, were still tiny youngsters to tuck up in bed.

And she had no memory at all of the existence her youngest child James — now 20.

The ex-care home manager, 55, said: “In my last memory, Maggie Thatcher was Prime Minister and John Major was hovering around.

“I’ve been told that a guy called Tony Blair got in for a while, but I don’t remember him.

“I used to love EastEnders. But I watched it since the accident and I couldn’t believe that Pauline Fowler was dead. It’s like a completely different soap.”

The death of Princess Diana, 9/11, the rise of the smartphone and the glory days of Britpop with bands such as Oasis had also never happened in her mind.

Kay admitted: “When I heard modern music, I was really surprised. What happened to Meat Loaf and Black Sabbath? I do like that Adele woman though.”

But it is the loss of the childhoods of her kids that has been the hardest to bear since she slipped on a wet floor at work on July 25 last year.

The mum of three from Newton, Cambs — who revealed her memory loss in The Sun on Thursday — said: “What kind of mother forgets their children?

“I was convinced my daughter was a stranger having an affair with my partner and I couldn’t even remember I’d given birth to my youngest son.

“My family showed me photographs to try to spark memories. But it’s like looking through a stranger’s family album.

“I feel robbed of my own kids. I can’t even begin to describe my sense of loss I feel every day.” And she still feels too fragile to come to terms with her mother’s death during her lost years.

She said: “When I woke up in the hospital after my accident, I tried to phone my mum. I had no idea she was dead.

“I can’t remember my last goodbye with her, which is extremely painful.

“Her death is something I have put to the back on my mind to deal with when I am stronger.”

As well as retrograde amnesia, Kay’s accident also left her with short-term memory loss. She also mixes up everyday habits — she will accidentally use hairspray as deodorant, and make coffee without boiling the kettle.

She now relies on the Post-it note reminders scattered around the house — and on her partner of five years Robert, 60, He gave up his own car business to be her full-time carer — and has to tell her each morning as she gets up to go to work that she no longer has a job.

He said: “I still miss the ‘real’ her. But I never wanted to leave her side.” The two plan to wed next year, and Kay is also looking forward to daughter Sandy becoming a mum in three months’ time.

She said of learning of the baby: “I was shocked. In my head I’m still in my thirties.

“I still feel like a mother of toddlers so it is hard to get my head around how I should behave as a grandmother.

“But I’m also really excited. It feels like a chance to start a new chapter. It won’t make up for the memories of my own daughter that I’ve lost, but it will help.”

For more information on brain injury, see headway.org.uk.

pages.subdeck: Shock ... Kate Tolman discovered child porn images on her partner's phone
pages.headline: Day boyfriend moved in with me and my three kids I found out he was a paedo ...I locked him in until police arrived
pages.teaser: HOW one devastated mum shopped the man she had planned her future with
pages.articlebody:
WHEN smitten Kate Tolman helped her lover move into the house she shared with her three children, she saw their future clearly – a happy family in a loving home.

And their new life began idyllically on the morning of their first full day together when Paul Scott got up to bring her coffee in bed.

While he was clattering around in the kitchen, the mobile phone he had left on the bedside table rang.

And as she fumbled with it she found herself looking at photos that instantly shattered her dreams and turned love into hate.

The carpenter’s phone was filled with images of sick child porn.

Mum of three Kate, now 37, told The Sun: “I felt physically sick. I felt like I’d been winded — I couldn’t believe I’d been sharing my life and my bed with a paedophile.”

Support worker Kate had been dating Scott for two years before she invited him to share the home in Saltash, Cornwall, where she had lived with her two daughters and son since splitting from their father three years earlier.

She had met him on a night out with friends in Plymouth in August 2007, when pals dared her to dance with a stranger and she homed in on Scott, who was alone at the bar. Kate recalled: “He wasn’t much of a looker and seemed really awkward dancing but he was polite and a good sport.

“We decided to go for a meal a few days later.

“When he arrived, he was glowing bright red and his skin was peeling from sunburn after roofing all day.

“I couldn’t help but laugh about it and Paul did too. He was always ready to share a joke, even if it was at his own expense.

“That’s one of the things that made me fall for him.”

The pair were soon constantly texting and phoning and Kate’s feelings for Scott were soon turning serious.

She said: “It was my first relationship in a while and I wasn’t looking for anything at all, but he really won me over.

“I could tell I was falling for him after a few weeks.” Within 12 months, the couple were spending all of their time together and her kids — who are now teenagers — liked him too. In October 2009 they decided to move in together.

Kate said: “Everything with Paul was easy. I felt so comfortable and secure with him. I thought we knew each other inside and out.

“I was completely in love and ready to share my life and my family with him.”

So Kate was excited as she helped him clear out his old place before welcoming him into her home for their first night as live-in lovers.

She said: “We’d packed all of his things into the car the night before but were too tired to unload them.

“In the morning he’d gone downstairs to make me a coffee and was taking for ever.

“When I called his mobile to joke about how long it was taking, his phone vibrated on the table by me.

“I reached over to delete the missed call but accidentally knocked another button and opened the pictures folder.”

Kate flicked through the photos, smiling as she saw how often she featured. There were snaps of her and Scott together, a birthday cake, and even a picture of her taken the night they met for the first time at the Plymouth club.

She said: “I was looking through the pictures and felt really touched. Then I spotted a folder called Other Files.

“I’d never looked through Paul’s phone before — but I became curious and couldn’t help myself.”

She clicked on the folder and it took her brain a few seconds to process what she was seeing — a sick photo of a girl who appeared to be younger than ten.

Shaking with disgust, she kept clicking through the files — finding more and more vile images of young girls.

She recalled: “I was stunned. I felt sick. He was moving in with me and my three children — it doesn’t bear thinking about.

“I couldn’t believe that someone so close to me was a paedophile. I knew I had to go to the police immediately.”

With extraordinary presence of mind, Kate swung into action to do what she needed to do — shield her kids, then make sure both Scott and the photos were handed over to the authorities.

The brave mum said: “I told the kids to go to their friends’ houses.

“By this stage Paul was in the bathroom and as soon as they had left I began banging on the door.

“He seemed really panicked. When I held the phone up and showed him the pictures he started trying to explain.”

Scott also tried to grab the phone and there was a frantic tussle.

Kate said: “All I was worried about was keeping him and the pictures in the house until the police could come.

“He ran downstairs and I chased after him to lock the front door. I was in such a hurry I didn’t even get dressed.”

She then locked Scott in the kitchen and dialled 999.

Kate said: “I was so angry. Never did something like this ever enter my head. I racked my brain, trying to think if I had missed anything. I was thinking of my own children too. Imagine if he had tried to touch them?

“I was absolutely distraught but had no doubt about reporting him. What Paul did was disgusting and at that moment all I could think about were the poor girls from the photographs.”

Police were soon on the scene and Scott was taken away in a van while a traumatised Kate gave a statement.

But the most difficult moment of the day was still to come.

She said: “I had to have the worst conversation of my life with my children. I had to ask them if my partner had touched them.

“I had all sorts of nightmares whirring around my head.

“I could hardly breathe when I asked them if he had hurt them. That moment was one of the most frightening of my life.”

But her kids assured her that he had never approached them. Kate recalled: “That was such a relief.”

Cops searched Scott’s possessions and found nearly 400 images of child porn on his phone and a total of four computers, including Kate’s own laptop.

In July last year, Scott, 42, was sentenced to 30 weeks in jail after being found guilty of 13 counts of making and possessing 391 indecent images of children between September 2006 and October 2009.

He will also have to sign the sex offenders’ register for ten years.

Kate, who gave evidence at the trial, said: “When I saw him in the dock, I felt nothing but contempt for him.

“Anyone who thinks a friend, partner or relative is a paedophile needs to stand up and be counted. Victims and families don’t have to live in the shadows of what these people have done.

"I got in the witness box and testified with my head held high.

“That’s one less paedophile who can hurt kids.”

pages.headline: 'We’re all willing Gail to get better ...I’ve told her to put a picture of our daughter on her wall in rehab'
pages.teaser: DAN Hipgrave, Gail Porter’s ex-hubby, on her battle with booze
pages.articlebody:
JUST days before she checked into rehab, Gail Porter agreed to meet her ex-husband Dan Hipgrave and his new wife Lynsey for a picnic on London’s Hampstead Heath.

To anyone passing on that summer’s day, it must have seemed the typical extended family get-together.

For also with them as they munched sandwiches and enjoyed the sunshine was the former couple’s adorable nine-year-old daughter, Honey.

But the happy scene masked years of torment that have blighted Gail’s life and threatened to separate her from the little girl she treasures.

In an exclusive interview, today Toploader guitarist Dan speaks for the first time about his strained relationship with the troubled TV presenter, who had her first breakdown shortly after they separated.

He reveals how he and Lynsey are doing everything they can to offer Honey stability while Gail tackles her rehabilitation.

And he tells how he advised Gail to use their daughter’s image to help her through her darkest hours.

Dan said: “I spoke to Gail just before she checked into rehab and I told her to put a picture of Honey on her bedroom wall.

“I said, ‘If you look at that picture every day, that is what is going to get you through.’

“Rehab will be tough for Gail but this is her last chance to get better and I think she knows that.

“And she has to get better. Gail has so much to live for. I keep telling her, ‘You have everything going for you. You have an amazing daughter, people who love you — and you are incredibly talented.’

“I have absolutely no doubt in my mind that if Gail can get healthy she will be able to revive her career. But she doesn’t have many more chances left — and that is why we are keeping everything crossed for her.”

Dan, 37, opened his heart to The Sun shortly after his ex checked herself into one of the world’s toughest rehab centres last week.

Gail will spend the next three months undergoing intensive counselling at a pioneering treatment facility in Cape Town, South Africa.

As part of the radical programme, her mobile phone will be confiscated and she will have minimal contact with the outside world.

The regime will be a stern test for former Top Of The Pops presenter Gail, 41, who will only be allowed to contact little Honey through the online video service Skype.

But it will also be an ongoing ordeal for those close to Gail who have had to pick up the pieces.

Dan said: “When anyone writes about Gail, I am portrayed as the bad guy who ruined her life or the stay-at-home dad who looks after her daughter while she dips in and out of rehab.

“I have even been blamed for her losing her hair. For years now I have wanted to scream from the rooftops that I am not this horrible person.

“I also want people to know I am not a footnote in her life story. As tough as this has been on Gail, it was far from easy for the rest of us.”

Dan and Gail were one of the hottest couples of their generation when they married at a register office in her hometown of Edinburgh in 2001.

He was the guitarist in a band dubbed the “new Oasis” after their Dancing In The Moonlight track hit the charts. She was the TV presenter who became a lads��� mag favourite before her naked image was beamed on to the Houses of Parliament as part of an ad campaign.

They met during a bender organised by Chris Evans after they both appeared on his TFI Friday show.

Dan admits their relationship got caught up in Nineties excess.

He said: “That whole period was a bit of a blur, to be honest.

“I know that during our first year together we were both so busy we only saw each other about once a month. So our relationship was built on pretty flimsy foundations.

“You only have to look at the timeline of our relationship to see what a whirlwind it was.

“We got married and had Honey about a year later. Then I went straight on tour.

“Gail suffered from post-natal depression but, like many men, I struggled to recognise the symptoms.

“Then, when I came back, Gail went off to America to film Dead Famous and I stayed in London with Honey. I hardly saw her for a year.

“By this point I realised we were different people and knew the end of our relationship was near.”

Asked how bad the relationship got, Dan says: “It was fiery but I think some things should be kept private. Her personality is so big it can fill a room. But sometimes the person who talks the loudest at a party is also the least happy.”

Dan says he and Gail broke up around a year after their daughter was born, although they did not officially divorce for a couple of years.

That same year — 2005 — Gail revealed she was suffering from the hair loss condition alopecia. She also had her first breakdown.

Despite their divorce, Dan reveals that in the midst of her crisis he was the person she called. He said: “She left a voicemail on my phone and I could tell she was not well.

“I went down to the house and she was not in a good state. I think she might have overdosed on something, although I can’t be sure.

“I called for an ambulance and they told me to make sure she stayed awake. I didn’t know what to do so I walked her around the room.”

Dan has since found happiness with Lynsey, a sports presenter for Al Jazeera Sports and BBC Radio Five Live, who he married in 2008.

Dan said: “Lynsey and I met in 2006 in north London when we were introduced by a mutual friend, Chris Moyles. We got married in Lynsey’s home town of Newcastle where Honey was a bridesmaid.

“Lynsey is now a huge part of Honey’s life and they enjoy a really strong relationship.”

Meanwhile, 2008 saw a “defining moment” in Gail’s life when she was sectioned after her then boyfriend Jonny Davies reported she was suicidal. She claims she was never serious about taking her own life.

But Dan says: “I have to take my hat off to Jonny. He was the first person who forced her to get help.”

He says he and his wife have provided a level of stability in Honey’s life that Gail appreciates. The couple are now leaving London to live in the countryside with his daughter. But Dan insists this has nothing to do with his ex’s problems.

He said: “I would never stop Gail from seeing Honey. Gail likes it that Lynsey gets on so well with Honey.

“Just before Gail went to rehab we all went to Hampstead Heath together for a picnic and Honey and Gail had a really nice time.”

He added: “Gail has been in and out of rehab this year, but obviously it has not worked for her. Honey has dealt with it remarkably well.

“Gail has to complete this programme then stay healthy. I’ve told her, ‘When you get back I want to see the new Gail Porter.’

“Gail and Honey have a very special relationship. I know she is not going to let that bond slip away.

“And I honestly cannot wait for the day when she is better.”

pages.articlebody:
IT’S a debate that men and women have been having for donkey’s years – what’s better, natural or fake?

Plastic surgery has become commonplace in the celebrity world.

But some stars have managed to stay looking trim without going under the knife.

Biz takes a look at the hits and misses of real versus fake...

Kate Upton

Despite being branded fat by one clueless website, the US model was voted as having the best bum in the world by Sun readers.

Heidi Montag

The reality TV star had TEN procedures in a day. She claims not to regret it – despite looking like a Madame Tussauds exhibit.

Beyonce

Her bum is as famous as her music. She must have done plenty of booty-shaking to get back in shape so fast after giving birth in January.

Chloe Sims

The Towie gimp has had more work done than an old motor. She’s had two boob jobs as well as implants in her bottom.

Miranda Kerr

She was back to modelling Victoria’s Secret underwear in lightning-quick time after giving birth. AND hasn’t had any work done.

Lauren Pope

An all-natural look helped her to pull Prince Harry in 2004, but she’s since had a few nips and tucks. She is a Towie girl after all.

Jessica Alba

Another A-lister you wouldn’t know had recently had a sprog. Jess shows off her beach bod just four months after giving birth.

Tara Reid

The American Pie actress has admitted to having a boob job and lipo – which both went wrong. She looked better to start with.

Helen Mirren

Despite being 67, this Dame still puts much of Hollywood to shame. She has slammed youngsters for using plastic surgery.

Sharon Osbourne

She is no stranger to plastic surgery. OZZY’s missus has spent more than £120,000 on procedures. She wears it well, though.

Kelly Brook

Kelly is every bloke’s dream. She’s all natural and regularly parades her body in bikinis. Her fella Thom Evans is a lucky man.

Coco

ICE T’s wife often posts pictures online of herself wearing very little, but insists her ample behind is all natural. We’re not convinced.

pages.subdeck: Depraved ... sect leader Faizrakhman Satarov
pages.headline: Cult caged 27 kids in honeycomb of cells...underground
pages.teaser: YOUNG victims of depraved Russian sect were never allowed to see the light of day as they were held as prisoners
pages.byline: From WILL STEWART in Kazan, Russia
pages.articlebody:
ON the outside it looks like a normal two-storey brick house.

But beneath its foundations is an “eight-level ant hill” where 70 people — including 27 children — have lived in a “Muslim state” underground in the middle of Russia.

Most of the youngsters have never even seen the outside world, let alone attended school or seen a doctor.

The oldest — aged 17 — was found to be pregnant when police broke their way in and released the young inhabitants.

And the youngest “victim” is just 18 months old.

They were all followers of the reclusive sect’s 83-year-old white-bearded leader Faizrakhman Satarov, who declared himself a prophet.

Reports yesterday alleged that sect children had sex once they reached their teens, an unconfirmed claim now being investigated by Russian police who fear paedophile crimes.

According to state TV, Satarov had also declared his house an independent Islamic state, building a honeycomb of windowless, unventilated cells where many followers were prisoners.

One woman sect member lost her child, evidently from shock, as she was evacuated from her underground home.

For more than a decade Satarov’s followers were condemned to live in squalid and cramped cells. They were dug out of eight different levels beneath the house near the mainly Muslim city of Kazan, capital of Russia’s Tatarstan region on the River Volga.

One report said there was as little as one cubic metre (35 cubic feet) for every three people.

A police officer emerging from the bunker said: “It’s an underground prison, a vision of hell, not some Muslim paradise.”

The FSB secret service — the successor to the KGB — was also involved in the operation to bring the sect back into the real world.

A local TV journalist who inspected the labyrinth said: “Daylight does not reach the cells as all of them are located underground.

“This eight-level underground ant hill has about 30 small rooms. Now police are demanding the destruction of the illegal underground compound.

“They will not touch a mosque or the house itself, only the underground premises where people actually lived but which were built illegally.”

But Gumer Ganiyev — Satarov’s deputy — vowed: “They will come with bulldozers and guns but they can demolish this house over our dead bodies.”

A police video of last week’s raid showed bearded male residents shouting as investigators forced their way inside the building.

Women wearing traditional headscarves were highlighted carrying young children, including babies, up a long flight of stairs from deep underground.

A police officer ordered: “Take these children to a bus.”

Police investigator Ranis Bakhitov said the children were “living in unsanitary conditions. There is a lack of ventilation. The premises are like monks’ cells.”

He added: “Based on the evidence of police officers, all the children require medical attention. The space was built as a labyrinth.”

The children were said to be basically healthy — but dirty — when they were checked over at hospital.

Doctor Tatyana Moroz said: “The children were in satisfactory condition. They were all fed, although they were dirty...

“Tomorrow the full analysis will be finished and we will give our final conclusion about the condition of their health.”

Police have charged four members of the bizarre group — called “muammin” from the Arabic word for believers — with child abuse.

A wide-ranging probe is now under way into other possible crimes.

Astonishingly, the authorities have known of the sect’s existence and the presence of children since 2007, yet failed to act. It was unclear if they had full knowledge of the appalling conditions.

Satarov somehow managed to slip though the net of first the Soviet Union and later independent Russia.

A police source said that in 1996 the cult leader secured land for an Islamic school and “gradually all the members of the sect moved there to live permanently”.

“His supporters led a closed way of life, not leaving their shelter without extreme necessity. The children of the commune grew up in the same conditions. They did not go to educational and medical institutions, which is the most severe breach of children’s rights.”

A handful of trusted Satarov loyalists had been permitted to work in local markets to earn money for the group.

Last night Satarov was said to be “bedridden and delirious” in hospital.

He had declared himself an Islamic prophet in the mid-Sixties during the Leonid Brezhnev era after interpreting sparks from a trolleybus cable as a divine light from God.

Satarov, formerly a Muslim mufti (an Islamic scholar), founded his sect in the Seventies despite curbs on all religious groups in the USSR.

His sect does not recognise Russian state law or the authority of Tatarstan’s mainstream Muslim leaders. His followers were encouraged to read his manuscripts.

He has been charged with “taking the law into his own hands”, said assistant prosecutor Irina Petrova.

The underground mothers and fathers were charged with neglecting their parental obligations.

The children were discovered last week when police searched the sect grounds as part of a probe into the recent killing of a leading Tatarstan Muslim cleric.

Radical Islamist groups were blamed but there seems to be no link to Satarov’s outfit.

He was known as a fundamentalist and in a 2008 interview he said he fell out with other clerics and authorities in the Communist era.

The KGB allegedly sent him to Muslim nations on propaganda trips spreading stories about religious freedom in the officially atheist Soviet Union. He said: “That’s how I became satan’s servant, a traitor.

“When I understood that, I repented and started preaching.”

Kazan-based theologian Rais Suleimanov said: “Islam postulates that there are no other prophets after Muhammad. The teachings of Satarov, who declared himself a prophet, have been rejected by traditional Muslims.”

Officers entered Satarov’s bizarre complex last Friday as they investigated the killing of Valiulla Yakupov, Tatarstan’s deputy chief mufti. He was shot dead last month as he left his house in Kazan.

The sect case echoes that of a 35-member Doomsday sect that holed up in an underground cave in a region south-east of Moscow in 2007, only emerging after the end of the world failed to materialise.

In this latest case, the rescued youngsters are in the care of local orphanages. Pavel Astakhov, ombudsman for children, has taken personal charge of ensuring that they can overcome their ordeal.

He said: “Unfortunately, the victims of the sect will need professional rehabilitation over a fairly long period. The sect member parents must first undergo treatment before they are reunited with the children.”

These children may have been rescued from a living hell — but they could spend a lifetime recovering.

pages.subdeck: Life or death ... postcode lottery sees some cancer patients denied treatment
pages.headline: We need help first
pages.teaser: TWO women reveal the impact it has had on their lives
pages.articlebody:
PM David Cameron has come under fire for the £11.5billion the Government spends on foreign aid while patients here are denied life-saving drugs.

As a guest on London’s LBC radio, he was played a recording left for him by a cancer sufferer called Anna, 68, from Finchley, north London.

She sobbed: “No foreign aid is being cut, and I’m waiting for treatment that’s not on the national health.”

A postcode lottery means hundreds of patients are denied life-saving cancer treatment on the NHS — while others are given it for free.

Here, LYNSEY HAYWOOD talks to two women about the impact it has had on their lives.

Yvonne, 57, from north Wales

RETIRED council worker Yvonne Briscoe lives in Brynford, north Wales, with her husband Michael, 61.

She rents a flat 53 miles from her home so she can access bowel cancer treatment.

Yvonne says: “I first started suffering symptoms in 2008 and my doctor thought it was irritable bowel syndrome.

“By the time I got diagnosed the cancer had spread to my lungs and my liver.

“I started chemo at Glan Clwyd Hospital. Last October doctors said it wasn’t working any more. Then a friend told me about the drug Cetuximab.

“I applied for funding but was turned down so I was left with no choice.

“The only way I could get it was renting a flat in Stockport as getting funding for Cetuximab in England is easier.

“The NHS is meant to cover the whole country — it doesn’t.

“Battling cancer is hard enough and having to travel while unwell only adds to that.

“I have to pay £40 in petrol a week for the journey and it’s £400 a month to rent the flat.

“But this is nothing compared to the cost of my life.

“It hurts to know the Government is sending so much money abroad when we really need it here.

“I sympathise, but isn’t this what we pay our taxes for?

“So far the drug seems to be shrinking the tumours.

“I’m not saying it will work for all of us but shouldn’t we be given the chance?”

Karen, 33, from Lincolnshire

KAREN BANNISTER lost her beloved husband Mark after he had been refused funding for brain cancer drug Avastin.

Soldier Mark, 38, from Gainsborough, Lincs, who was diagnosed in 2003, died in June leaving behind Karen and their kids Sophie, seven, and five-year-old Thomas.

Karen, right with Mark, says: “During his nine years in the Army Mark served in Bosnia and Northern Ireland.

“He knew how much help is needed in other countries, but how can we help others before we help ourselves? Billions is spent on foreign aid.

“We assumed he would get the drug but the nearest surgery where Mark would have been allowed the treatment was five miles away.

“The only way we could get the drug for Mark was to register at a doctor in Sheffield and say Mark was living at a friend’s address. Within 24 hours his application had been approved. Within a week he was having his first treatment.

“We felt bad about lying but we had gone down the moral route and spent six months fighting for nothing. Unless you are in that situation you can’t imagine what it’s like. If he had got it sooner I believe it would have helped him.

“The kids ask all the time when their dad is coming home and I don’t think it has sunk in for them yet.

“Mark fought so hard for the rights of cancer sufferers while he was alive. I intend to keep on fighting in his memory.”

Where your money goes

THE Government is set to spend £11.5billion on aid this year. Here are the ten countries handed the most by Britain in 2011.

£324.1m went to ETHIOPIA for healthcare, education and water – though critics say little reaches those who really need it.

£268.4m to INDIA for projects like school-building and fighting domestic abuse, but some may be lost to corruption.

£215.8m to PAKISTAN for training and school-building. Angers Tories as country spends more on Army than education.

£202.8m to BANGLADESH to battle effects of climate change and help businesses. Critics say lots is lost to corruption.

£171.5m to NIGERIA on education, family planning and immunisation. Critics say it could use its own huge oil revenues.

£153.9m to AFGHANISTAN to help it recover from war and Taliban rule. Critics fear it is a potentially hostile nation.

£142.7m to DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO on education and basic health but critics fear it is not getting to neediest.

£141m to TANZANIA on poverty-reduction to give the country a boost as it enjoys new political and economic stability.

£102.9m to SOMALIA to help bring stability to Mo Farah’s birth country after 20 years of conflict and humanitarian crises.

£94.3m to KENYA to aid stability through education, job creation and fighting malaria. Critics say Kenya has its own money.

Life-savers’ price

HERE is how much cancer drugs cost:

AVASTIN – for bowel, brain, lung and kidney cancer. Cost: £20,800 for a ten-month course.

CETUXIMAB – for bowel and colon cancer. Cost: £8,463 for a 12-week course.

VELCADE – for myeloma, cancer of bone marrow. Cost: £18,000 per patient per cycle.

SUNITINIB – for kidney cancer, stomach tumours. Cost: Six-week cycle is £3,139.

DASATINIB – for leukaemia. Cost: £30,477 per year.

myView

By TREVOR KAVANAGH

DAVID CAMERON himself admits billions in foreign aid has been “wasted” – though he blames the last Labour regime for most of it.

Much of our hard-earned cash was funnelled into the Swiss bank accounts of foreign tyrants or used to fund oppression or simply squandered.

Tragically, some of it still is, despite the best efforts of the Coalition-run Department for International Development.

Spending is scrutinised for value and targeted on projects that repay Britain in diplomatic clout, they say. This is a powerful argument.

But it does not justify a 37 per cent RISE in spending at this time.

It does not merit a £11.5BILLION overseas budget while spending here on health, education and defence is frozen or slashed.

And there is evidence that even where money reaches its target, it does more harm than good.

Experts warn we undermine fragile local infrastructures, distort exchange and interest rates – and support corruption.

In a word, Prime Minister, charity begins at home.

myView

By ANDREW MITCHELL, Secretary of State for International Development

AID is less than one per cent of Government spending but it is amazing value for money.

One baby every two seconds is vaccinated against killer diseases thanks to this money.

Every two hours, a mother’s life is saved.

And in the past year,we’ve fed 3.5million starving people in east Africa.

But Britain’s aid works in our own national interest too. It helps us tackle problems such as illegal immigration, terrorism, crime and disease at their source.

And we’ve ended aid to countries which didn’t need it, such as Russia and China – and set up a tough new aid watchdog to ensure our programmes get results.

The eyes of the world have been on this country for the past fortnight.

And as we rejoice in our sporting triumphs we do not forget those in need around the world.

pages.headline: Man boobs, rages and shrivelled testicles
pages.teaser: BODY-OBSESSED blokes may down steroids to bulk up like ‘real men’ – but the side-effects can make them more like monsters or even KILL
pages.articlebody:
BODY-OBSESSED blokes may down steroids to bulk up like “real men” – but the side-effects can make them more like monsters.

Beefed-up musclemen can end up sprouting breasts and covered in acne because of the hormones found in the illegal sports’ boosters.

And sometimes the drugs can even KILL.

But an investigation has found that there are more than 80 of the dodgy supplements on sale in Britain.

And experts fear that movies like Magic Mike, which featured Channing Tatum among super-buff strippers, may drive more Brits to steroids in a bid to get bodies like the stars.

David Carter, of the Medicines And Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, warned: “The products could contain unapproved ingredients that cause kidney failure, heart problems or seizures.”

Here, MATTHEW BARBOUR speaks to three men who have turned to drugs in a bid to achieve the perfect body.



Ed, 49

ED ‘SPYK’ GHEUR, 49, a retired professional rugby player from Brighton, took steroids every day from the age of 16 to 34, when he suffered a heart attack.

He has since written a book about his experience, to help raise awareness, called A Naughty Thing Called Life by Papa Spyk. He says:

When I was 16, I was introduced to steroids by a friend. I could exercise harder and for longer, I packed on lean muscle and the girls flocked to me. I soon became hooked.

As a professional rugby player in South Africa, I either injected or took oral steroids every day.

I grew “bitch tits” because of the excess oestrogen in my body. I had them surgically removed. I had terrible acne on my back and my testicles shrank to the size of peanuts.

But this seemed a small price compared with the attention, money and glamour of being so ripped.

After I retired from rugby, I became a model and stuntman in the US. I soon became addicted to cocaine, which cost £300 a day over eight years.

Everything changed one evening in 1997 when I was cooking dinner for my wife and my heart exploded.

My aorta, the largest blood vessel in the body, had split in half.

I faced having my legs amputated, which were miraculously partially saved by a surgeon, and all the organs in my body died.

I was in a coma for a month and intensive care for two more, needing more ops to replace my aorta with a plastic one.

My wife left me because she’d been told I’d almost certainly be brain dead and paraplegic.

I spent two years in bed recuperating, needing round-the-clock care, then five years in a wheelchair, very slowly learning to walk again.

I was told I would never be a father but got married and we had a girl who’s now six.

All I want now is to share my story so other people don’t do what I did.



Dennis, 29

DENNIS DX, who is single and from Nottingham, is a TV extra who has appeared on EastEnders, Holby City and Shameless. Using steroids caused severe mood swings and he has now stopped. He says:

I used to be a project manager for a charity which would build self-esteem in young people — ironic, as I started taking illegal substances to make myself feel and look better.

I began taking steroids in 2002 when I was 19 — my gym partner was taking them and he was getting bigger and I wanted to be as stacked as him.

I started weight training without steroids when I was 18 and went about four times a week.

However, you can only get so big without using steroids, even if you use all the protein shakes and any of the other hundreds of products available.

My training partner bought steroids from a contact of his — I never met the dealer, but they cost me £25 for 100 tablets.

I started taking only three a day as I was scared of side-effects, but within weeks I was up to 15 a day.

After I started taking them I’d work out six days a week and they really improved my body.

I noticed a difference within four weeks as they make you lift a lot more and you want to do more.

The testosterone boost gives you more power and determination.

I took tablets until 2008 when I moved on to injections.

I was more scared of the needles than the steroids because I had done a lot of research.

I administered the injections myself.

The first time was a bit scary — I nipped into the toilet at work and was worried I might do it wrong. You inject them into your bum — it’s quite awkward.

I got free needles from a needle exchange used by heroin users as well as steroid users.

I had injections twice a week, at a cost of £8 a shot.

I wanted to up the dose but it can be very bad for the heart.

They worked better than the tablets though and are supposed to be less harmful to your liver.

I didn’t tell my friends and family I was taking steroids as I would be embarrassed that I was taking harmful products just to make myself look better.

I eventually stopped in 2010. It was making me very aggressive.

I would get into fights in pubs and did some things I regret. If someone said something, I would react in a violent way and I wouldn’t back down. I didn’t like the person I was becoming.

I had on-off partners. If they noticed my aggression problems I would move on.

I looked good and there were plenty of fish in the sea.

Steroids didn’t shrink my penis or cause any hair loss, but they did affect my mood.

Friends were wary of me, as I could flip over something minor.

Eventually, when I stopped taking them, I told a few friends why I had been so aggressive and apologised.

I still work out five times a week.

I do miss my perfect body but steroids weren’t worth it.

I hope I stopped before the long-term effects took hold, but do worry I might have problems later in life.



Col, 40

COL WOOD, a former chef from Rugby, Warwickshire, fears taking steroids made him go blind in one eye. He says:

I’ve always loved playing rugby — I was never that big, weighing just 12st, but I always made up for that with my determination and strength. Certainly nobody ever messed with me on the pitch, but I suffered lots of injuries as a result.

When I got to around 32 the injuries started taking their toll, I wasn’t as fit as I used to be and I decided to take steroids.

I didn’t want to be some huge muscle-head, I just wanted to keep playing rugby at the level I was used to — I guess it was as much about my ego as anything.

I knew a few bouncers in the area, all of whom took steroids to get big, and through one I trusted got hold of some tablets and some liquid to inject.

Of course my wife Dawn, who’s a nurse, objected strongly but she knew I was going to do them whatever she said.

Within a matter of days I felt bigger and stronger and after my first course, which lasted about six months, I was up to 14st and loving my rugby.

I was lifting huge weights and knocking over guys almost twice my size. There were downsides, of course — I got really bad acne on my back and I noticed myself snapping all the time at the smallest irritation, although I knew never to snap at Dawn, who’d warned me I’d be out if I did.

But that all seemed a price worth paying.

When I got my second course of steroids, through the same doorman, that all changed. This batch was a mix of four different steroids but because I trusted the guy who got them for me I went with it.

It was almost the opposite of the first time — I got the shakes, almost like DTs or having flu.

I couldn’t eat, I felt utterly terrible and lost more weight than I’d put on in the first place, going down to just 10st.

I came off the steroids pretty quickly, but it was like they’d put my body into shut-down mode, and I didn’t recover.

I had to retire from playing rugby almost straight away.

It’s one of the main problems with steroids — they’re always imported and you never know what you’re putting into your body, so when it goes bad it goes really bad.

It doesn’t seem to matter what I ate or did, that weight wouldn’t come back on.

Coincidentally I also developed the rare eye disease uveitis then. Within months I was almost completely blind in my left eye and had to stop work as a chef.

Since my eyes have gone bad I’ve made it a real mission to work out ways people with disabilities can play sport — through the charity Fight To Walk I raise funds to provide prosthetic limbs.

Of course I wish I’d never taken steroids — but through all the people I meet now with disabilities I know life is too short and precious to wallow in self pity.

pages.articlebody:
STEP aside, Essex, there’s a brand new bronze capital of Britain – Oxford.

It seems the well-to-do ladies in the city of dreaming spires are determined not to be left in the shade when it comes to slapping on the fake bake. In fact, they prefer a darker shade of tan than women anywhere else in the land.

The surprise finding comes from a study by Very.co.uk, which showed women across the UK 15 different shades of tan and asked them which colour on the chart they most aspired to match.

The research found that women in Oxford not only go for the darkest orange option available but are also the most frequent tanners.

They hit the bottle five times a month compared with Brummie girls who top up their fake tans three times a month.

Reality TV star Amy Childs and the TOWIE brigade might be famed for their bright orange glow but Brentwood in Essex took a lowly fourth place in the bronze breakdown of Britain.

It trailed behind London and Cardiff which came second and third respectively.

Manchester-born women who love fake tan have been dubbed “Tancunians” because of their bronzed look, yet the survey showed they actually prefer a mid-range glow. Meanwhile, down the road, Liverpool lasses tend to settle on a slightly lighter shade.

And if a trendy “no-tan tan” is more your thing, you’ll probably be from the far north or the deepest south.

Brighton belles such as This Morning’s Holly Willoughby go for a very light shade on the tan chart, while Scottish girls, such as TV presenter Jenni Falconer, choose an even paler option.
