pages.headline: Statins are dodgy, change in diet better for the heart, say experts
pages.teaser: CARDIOLOGISTS say the cholesterol-lowering drugs, taken by 7million Brits, are not a cure-all for heart disease
pages.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health and Science Editor
pages.articlebody:
STATINS taken by seven million Brits are not the best way to prevent heart disease, a study has revealed.

Changing diet is more effective than the cholesterol-lowering pills in helping the heart and staving off strokes, say scientists.

The warning comes as figures show statins have had NO effect on Britain’s heart disease rate.

Cardiologists say the drugs — which cost the NHS £450million a year — have a role to play, but are not a cure-all.

Prof Kausik Ray, of St George’s Healthcare Trust, London, said: “Statins are an effective, cheap treatment but I’m not in favour of mass medication because everyone should be treated on an individual basis.

“For people with no family history of heart problems and others deemed a low risk, other approaches should be used, like eating a good diet full of fish, lean meat, vegetables and low in saturated fat.”

Exercise is also important to heart health, he added.

The professor is among experts contributing to a documentary to be aired next month called Statin Nation: The Great Cholesterol Cover-Up. The British Heart Foundation said statins played a “vital role” in lowering cholesterol and helping prevent heart attacks.

Spokeswoman Maureen Talbot added: “You may be able head off the prospect of being prescribed statins by eating a healthy, balanced diet, keeping physically active and maintaining a healthy weight and body shape.”

emma.little@the-sun.co.uk

MyView

By JUSTIN SMITH, Documentary maker

Around 75 per cent of the people who take a statin do not have a diagnosed heart problem. They are given the drug in the hope of preventing it in the future. But clinical trials have not shown any life extension when statins are used in this way.

In some cases, statins may very slightly reduce the chance of heart attack — but they can increase the risk of other serious diseases.

As Dr Malcolm Kendrick says in the documentary: “You might change what’s written on the death certificate, but you won’t change the date.”

pages.articlebody:
A NEW wardrobe, accessories to match, top-to-toe beauty treatments and even cosmetic surgery – holidays can cost a fortune before you have even left home.

And some women splash MORE cash preparing for their annual getaway than they do on the actual holiday itself.

Here, three women tell DIANA APPLEYARD how they broke the bank before their breaks.

Farin Sunshine

Preparation £7,200

Holiday £2,000

pages.headline: Is Britain going pop?
pages.teaser: WE reveal what pop is doing to our skin, bones, toes, brain, teeth, heart, lungs, pancreas and uterus
pages.articlebody:
ARE we all about to go pop?

A can of cola or lemonade provides an instant pick-me-up for most of us.

We’re also offered “healthy” sports aids from vending machines at the gym and huge sodas at the cinema.

But has our obsession with fizzy drinks gone too far?

Dr Hans-Peter Kubis has just led a study into what soft drinks do to our bodies and when you read what he has discovered, water might seem a better option.

A can a day, or even just two a week, may alter our metabolism so much that we pile on weight. The drinks also appear to raise the risk of heart disease, liver failure and hypertension.

This week, we ask if it’s time to end our love affair with fizzy drinks.

THIRSTY Brits guzzle around 14billion litres of soft drinks every year – and consumption has more than doubled since the mid-Eighties.

But now there are mounting fears that the country’s addiction to the fizz poses a serious health threat.

A new report by scientists at Bangor University shows sugar-laden drinks change the way the body’s metabolism works, potentially increasing the risk of type 2 diabetes.

And a series of other damning studies have found excessive consumption can damage virtually every part of your body.

Most consumers fail to realise just how much sugar these drinks contain, says Catherine Collins, chief dietician at St George’s Hospital, London.

It is sugar, rather than other ingredients, that does the bulk of the damage.

She says: “When people consume these drinks, they don’t think of the calories involved. Yet a can of soft drink can contain seven to ten teaspoons of sugar.

“That triggers a rapid rise in blood sugar, which makes the body produce more insulin to try to dispose of it.”

The pancreas, the organ which manufactures insulin, has to work harder to cope with the sugar load, which increases the chances of it malfunctioning, triggering diabetes.

The British Soft Drinks Association say 60 per cent of fizzy drinks sold in the UK are diet, low-calorie or no-added-sugar versions.

But that means we’re still guzzling more than 5.5billion litres of the “bad” kind.

Countries including France and Denmark have imposed taxes to cut consumption.

Here Sun Health looks at what pop is doing to our bodies.

SKIN

TOO many fizzy drinks could make you look old before your time.

A 2010 Harvard University study found that phosphate – a mineral which makes many soft drinks taste tangy – accelerated the ageing process in mice.

High doses withered the skin and muscle.

Levels tend to be even higher in the diet versions of fizzy drinks.

There is no direct evidence it does the same in humans, but experts advise: “Avoid phosphate toxicity.”

BONES

THREE or more cola-based drinks a day can thin the bones and raise the risk of osteoporosis, according to research by Tufts University in the US.

And it’s not just because they tend to replace milky drinks.

Scientists now think that phosphoric acid used in these drinks, whether diet or full fat, may disrupt the balance of calcium – vital to build strong bones – meaning it is lost from the body.

TOES

GOUT was once a problem solely for fat Victorian gents but recently it has made a comeback.

And one reason may be soaring fizzy drinks consumption. Scientists at the University of British Columbia found the agonising toe condition was 85 per cent more common in men who drank two or more cans a day.

They blame fructose, a type of sugar used in drinks that raises levels of uric acid in the blood – the main trigger for gout. It’s in fruit juice too, though the benefits of drinking fruit juice outweigh any risks.

BRAIN

JUST one full-sugar fizzy drink a day may be all it takes to affect behaviour.

Last year, a US study found teenage boys were up to 15 per cent more likely to be aggressive, violent and carry weapons if they had at least one daily can of pop. It tallies with other research suggesting poor nutrition may be a cause of antisocial behaviour.

Researchers said: “There was a significant association between soft drinks and violence.”

TEETH

FOUR cans of fizzy drinks a day raise the danger of tooth erosion by a whopping 252 per cent, according to a study in the British Dental Journal.

And going for a diet drink option probably won’t help either. It’s not the sugar that strips tooth enamel but the citric acid – the chemical that gives oranges, lemons and grapefruit their bite.

This is used in some drinks and also corrodes the tooth surface, causing pain and sensitivity.

HEART

SUGAR in fizzy drinks is thought to be the main threat to health. But experts at the University of Miami say the diet options may be just as bad, if not worse, when it comes to heart attacks and strokes.

They quizzed 2,500 people and found those downing just one diet soda a day were 61 per cent more likely to have cardiovascular problems than those avoiding the drinks.

It is not yet clear why diet drinks have this effect.

LUNGS

AS unlikely as it sounds, fizzy drinks may even adversely affect the lungs, increasing the risk of getting asthma.

Researchers at the University of Adelaide surveyed nearly 17,000 people and found those who drank the most “full-fat” cola, lemonade or flavoured mineral water had the highest rates of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease – an incurable lung condition that is often associated with smoking.

PANCREAS

THE pancreas – which is behind the stomach – pumps out insulin to help muscle cells burn sugar for fuel.

But just two full-sugar fizzy drinks a day can double the chances of developing pancreatic cancer.

One of the most lethal types of tumour, it killed Apple founder Steve Jobs last year. Sugar is to blame because boffins at Sweden’s Karolinska Institute found adding a couple of spoonfuls to tea or coffee also increased the dangers.

UTERUS

SUGARY drinks could raise the risk of pre-eclampsia, a potentially deadly condition that kills around 1,000 premature babies a year in the UK.

Mums-to-be were found to be 27 per cent more likely to develop it if they downed pop every day.

Affecting up to one in 20 pregnancies, pre-eclampsia occurs when blood vessels in the placenta do not develop properly. This can reduce oxygen and nutrient transfer to the baby.

pages.headline: Bankrupt by thirty
pages.teaser: ANNE Scales had a glamorous lifestyle on borrowed money, ending up £19,000 in debt
pages.articlebody:
IT’S the gender equality that women never wanted – for the first time in history they are being declared bankrupt as often as men.

Around 28,000 Brits went bankrupt in the three months from April 1 to June 30 this year.

And according to accountancy firm RSM Tenon, women made up 50 per cent of them.

Earlier this year, TV presenter Miquita Oliver, 28, revealed she had filed for the official status of legal insolvency.

The former Popworld host and self-confessed fashion addict – who was a bridesmaid for Lily Allen last year – made the move after failing to pay a tax bill for more than £170,000.

And she is not alone. The number of women aged under 30 who are filing for bankruptcy is also on the increase, the report found.

Here NIKKI WATKINS and JENNY FRANCIS talk to two women about the reality of being hit by bankruptcy in your 20s.

Anne Scales, 30



ANNE lived a glamorous lifestyle on borrowed money, ending up £19,000 in debt. The single saleswoman, from Surbiton, Surrey, was declared bankrupt in November last year. She says:

“My problems began when my parents gave me a credit card to take to university for emergencies.

I was skint one month and my friend suggested I use it to buy a few bits I needed. I suddenly realised I had thousands of Pounds right there at my fingertips.

Irresponsibly, in just a few months, I’d splashed out on clothes, nights out and make-up.

With my friends coming from rich backgrounds, I felt under pressure to live the same kind of lifestyle.

Despite having a student loan, my money quickly disappeared on a monthly £50 gym membership, £60 phone bill and nights out spending £150 on booze.

My boyfriend always wore designer clothes and I felt scruffy next to him. Worried he would go off me, I went on shopping sprees to Selfridges, spending £200 a time.

I also bought an Apple Mac for £700 because everyone else had one.

I had two credit cards maxed out to £1,000, a £3,000 overdraft and a loan of £4,000. For holidays I went to exotic places like Egypt, Greece and Barbados.

When I left university in 2002, I was in £9,000 of debt. It was silly but when I got a job in sales I felt pressure to keep up with the money my co-workers were spending and went on expensive nights out.

Despite working for a company who sold credit cards, I very rarely thought about my debt.

My first job in sales earned me £12,000 a year which was swallowed up by rent, council tax and bills. So when the bank called me and asked if I wanted to get a £7,000 loan to consolidate my debts it sounded like a good idea.

I then had all the cards free so was able to spend on them again.

I told myself when I got a good job I’d start paying the loans back properly, rather than just paying back the minimum as I was.

And I was allowed to increase the limits on the cards to £5,000 on one and £3,000 on the other.

But when I did manage to get a better job in sales, earning £3,000 a month after tax, I still only paid back a little over the minimum.

Knowing I was paying off some of it helped me convince myself it would eventually disappear.

I was even allowed another £10,000 loan from HSBC — they said it would help me pay off my debts.

It wasn’t until I was 27 and had been in debt for eight years that I started to worry how I was going to pay the money back. I had no income, as I lost my job, and no way to pay back all the companies that were hounding me.

When I worked out my debt, it came to £18,000 over two credit cards, loans and overdrafts. I was terrified.

I told my family and they suggested I contact someone for help so I sought advice from the Citizens Advice Bureau. They recommended I file for bankruptcy.

When I was declared bankrupt in November it was terrifying to hear those words. I thought of bankrupt people as being irresponsible and was embarrassed about the state I had got myself into.

Now I can’t get a mortgage or apply for any loans or credit for at least six years.

I am still unemployed and have been looking for work for more than a year. I can barely go out or afford to buy myself a lipstick.

This is not where I saw myself being at the age of 30.

Sarah-Jane Lynch, 25

SARAH-JANE was declared bankrupt at just 20 when she found herself £14,000 in debt after recklessly spending on three credit cards. The student, from Edinburgh, says:

My problems with money started when I left school aged 17 and took up a part-time job at a post office.

I lived at home with my parents rent-free, so I spent a lot of money on clothes.

When I was 18 I became a sales co-ordinator for a house builder.

I took out a credit card with a limit of £1,000 to help fund clothes shopping and nights out and I maxed it out.

With money coming in from my £13,000-a-year salary I just about managed the minimum payments each month.

In the run-up to Christmas 2005, and needing money for presents, I applied for three credit cards thinking I’d only get approved for one.

The cards had a combined balance of £4,800 and, to my complete surprise, I was accepted for all three.

I don’t know what came over me, but I went into a spending frenzy.

It felt like it was my money and I blew nearly all the cash on lavish Christmas gifts and clothes for myself.

Then the repayments started coming through.

In January 2006 I was forced to take out a £4,000 loan, aiming to pay off as much of my credit card debt as possible.

I managed to pay off £1,000, but then my car got damaged and I was forced to use the other £3,000 for repairs.

I was left with monthly repayments of £273 for the loan and a £200 minimum payment on the £4,300 credit card debt. On top of my living costs it was impossible to balance the books.

I was too scared to tell my parents, so I just buried my head in the sand.

Stupidly the only thing that made me feel better was shopping to excess. I obtained a catalogue account and used up the £500 limit, a credit card and overdraft which amounted to £2,000, and a Capital One credit card with a £500 limit and spent it all on clothes and make-up.

But then the phone calls and letters started.

I couldn’t afford the repayments and tried to hide them hoping it would all go away.

By May 2007 I was getting threatened with legal action.

I was terrified of the post arriving and dreaded answering the phone in case it was a debt collector. At breaking point and not being able to see a future without financial troubles, I decided enough was enough.

So I entered into a trust deed — a Scottish alternative to bankruptcy — in June 2007.

I was more than £14,000 in debt and I felt that it was my only way out. My debt was wiped and I had to pay £3,600 in £100 monthly repayments over three years.

I could finally see the light at the end of the tunnel. And although I felt bad about not paying the money back, I saw no other way out. I knew I’d been silly and irresponsible.

I couldn’t get any form of credit or have a bank account during this time, but I discovered a small savings bank in Scotland who didn’t run credit checks.

I managed to get a new account and started managing my finances properly, which has meant I was able to go into business.

Normally you can’t have your own business if you have been declared bankrupt.

I have just finished an honours degree in business at Edinburgh Napier University and I’m about to launch a skincare brand this summer.

Being declared bankrupt in my twenties was terrifying and I’ve well and truly learned my lesson.”

The gay Torchwood star reckons he could help rogue adolescents clean up their acts. The actor — who plays Captain Jack in the Dr Who spin-off — admitted he and architect husband Scott Gill hope to one day adopt but are waiting for John’s career to settle down.

He said: “We haven’t ruled out having children ourselves but it depends where my career takes us. We wouldn’t want a baby. We’d look at adopting an older child or teenager who might have been in trouble.

“We would also look at adopting a gay child, thrown out of their home because of their sexuality.

“We have a lot to offer — chances and opportunities a young teen probably wouldn’t normally get.”

But he says his adoption plans could be put on hold while he works on the pilot for a new series in the States.

pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI last night landed England midfielder Jack Rodwell in a £15million deal.

But the Manchester City boss still wants more new players — despite picking up the season’s first piece of silverware with yesterday’s Community Shield win over Chelsea.

Mancini said: “I liked Jack last year and for this reason we bought him.

“He is a good player who needs to improve to play at this level. But he is young. I think he’s a good player for our future. We are still looking for other players. We are interested in all good players.”

Mancini has begged City chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak and football administrator Brian Marwood for the cash to splash on more new blood.

Khaldoon is keen to smooth the waters between Mancini and Marwood and the Italian added: “I speak with Khaldoon always.

“Every manager is unhappy when, one week before the start of the season, we haven’t bought any players. But I hope we can do something about that this week.”

Rodwell, 21, had a medical last night before completing his move to the champions from Everton.

The injury-prone star could cost another £6m if he proves a success.

Mancini added: “I’m sure that in a couple of years he will be a top, strong midfielder.”

City’s boss remains keen on Daniel Agger of Liverpool and Swansea’s Scott Sinclair, while he has also been linked with Robin van Persie, Napoli’s Edinson Cavani and Javi Martinez of Athletic Bilbao.

City saw off the Blues after Fernando Torres had put the Londoners ahead.

Yaya Toure, Carlos Tevez and Samir Nasri made it 3-1 — with Branislav Ivanovic being sent off — before Ryan Bertrand ended the scoring.

Mancini said of an eye-catching Tevez display: “This is the first time in the last four or five years he has had a pre-season and that’s important.”

Chelsea chief Roberto di Matteo admitted the defending champions will take some stopping.

He said: “They’re the favourites, no doubt about it, and we must catch up 25 points from last season.

“I felt we competed well before the red card. I thought there was no intention from our player to hurt the opposition.”

pages.subdeck: OUR HEROES ... Team GB's medalists gather to show off their spoils at the Olympic Park
pages.headline: OUR FINEST HOUR
pages.teaser: STEVEN HOWARD says the whole country has been reborn after our real sporting heroes took to the stage in London
pages.articlebody:
IT all started with four simple words: Good evening, Mr Bond.

Not M, not Q but the Queen, the first and most illustrious of Sebastian Coe’s 70,000 volunteers.

She understood completely and entered into the whole magical spirit of the Olympics.

Ever since we have been, if you will pardon the pun, in Oh, Oh, Heaven.

Last night the Olympic flame was extinguished and the torch handed on to Rio de Janeiro.

If Brazil has half as much fun as us — and knowing the Rio carnival, the persuasive influence of the samba and some of the most beautiful girls in the world, they will — the next Olympics is in good hands.

So the London Games are over and we can all return to a rather more mundane way of life.

We may have to be in therapy for some time.

What an Olympics it has been. From Danny Boyle’s rich and quirky opening ceremony to last night’s celebration of our long musical heritage, it has been a triumph.

Despite all the usual scare stories, the closer we got to the start of it all, the more we became enthused.

Personally, as we now wave the XXX Olympiad “au revoir”, I have to confess this has been the most life-affirming sporting extravaganza I have ever experienced.

It has been the most uplifting time in our island history for 67 years or so, the reclaiming of a national identity not seen since millions packed the Mall in front of Buckingham Palace at the end of the Second World War.

Over the last three weeks we have seen Great Britain reborn and at its best.

At the centre of it all have been the crowds that have flocked to every single event, cheering on not just the home athletes who have accumulated the largest tally of gold medals in over a century but every single competitor.

None more than Sarah Attar, who became the first woman in Saudi history to compete in track and field. The 19-year-old may have finished her 800 metres heat some 45 seconds behind the winner but she received the greatest ovation of all.

Yet Attar was ignored by nearly all the media outlets back in Saudi just as Wojdan Shahrkhani had been in the first week when she became the first Saudi Olympian when she competed in the judo.

Instead, attention focused on the bronze medal won by the showjumping team led by a member of the Saudi ruling family.

And what reward for the two brave girls who defiantly stood up against the awful degradation and repression in their country?

They were abused, told they would be shunned from here-on in and that they had sacrificed their place in the after-life.

So three more cheers for Sarah and Wojdan, two true golden girls.

The support for the Games has been truly outstanding. We first noticed it on the opening Saturday when the streets of London and the Surrey countryside were mobbed by almost 1.5million people as they came out in their droves to support the men’s road race.

We really could have been over the other side of the Channel watching the Tour de France.

We always joke about being proud to be British but that was one of those moments.

Then there was the ear-splitting roar that greeted Jess Ennis on the morning of her first appearance in the heptathlon — the first day of a track and field programme that was sold out every day for the first time in Olympic history.

It sent a shiver down your spine.

So did the reception later that evening for Ethiopia’s Tirunesh Dibaba when she retained her 10,000 metres title.

There was no particular reason for hats to be thrown into the air and the roof raised but it still happened.

Again, you felt so proud of everyone for their sportsmanship, fair play and the fact they were having such a stupendous time.

And then there were the individual moments. Double gold winner Charlotte Dujardin winning the blubbing gold after the dressage in Greenwich.

As I said, it was the Waterworks Olympics.

Some people say “whatever happened to the stiff upper lip?”

Well, we’ve changed — and for the better. We are no longer all closed up and afraid to show our emotions.

That’s why we saw big men like Chris Hoy dissolving at the first note of the national anthem.

And then there was lovely Victoria Pendleton, her bottom lip forever quivering. And all those rowers.

Best of all was Kat Copeland crossing the line at Eton Dorney with partner Sophie Hosking and yelling: “We’ve won the Olympics, we’re going to be on a stamp!”

What moments, what memories. Tear-jerkers like Gemma Gibbons winning her judo semi, remembering her mother Jeanette who had died of leukaemia eight years earlier and pointing to the sky and saying “I love you, mum.”

And Steve Redgrave lifting a shattered Mark Hunter out of his boat and hearing the distressed rower apologising for “only” winning silver.

And the stoic agony of open-water swimmer Keri-Anne Payne, in the Serpentine for almost two hours in the most brutal race of all — and losing out on a bronze by half a second.

Then there were the supreme moments of outstanding individual excellence — Usain Bolt, Mo Farah, Bradley Wiggins, Kirani James winning Grenada’s first-ever gold in the men’s 400 metres at just 19 and the peerless Kenyan David Rushida becoming the only man to break 1min 41sec in the 800m. And the USA women’s 4x100 squad dismantling the East German record that had stood for almost 30 years.

And in the last track and field event of them all, Bolt and his Jamaicans shattering the men’s 4x100 relay record. Then there were the ever-smiling, ever-courteous volunteers. And the Armed Forces personnel who made you feel that much safer.

And what a triumph for Coe, the man who made it all work.

And now it’s all over. And back to reality.

Real heroes to be replaced by mediocrity and Roo and Jay Tee. And non-entities like TOWIE, Big Brother and the rest of the Z-listers.

But for 17 glorious days of summer we basked in real achievement. Real heroes from home and abroad.

All of us — athletes, organisers, volunteers, a watching, thrilled and enthused public — deserve a pat on the back.

This, surely, has been our finest hour.

pages.subdeck: PROUD ... Jack Butland
pages.headline: Jack joy
pages.teaser: TEENAGE goalkeeper Jack Butland says it will be a ‘dream come true’ if he makes his senior debut against Italy
pages.articlebody:
TEENAGE goalkeeper Jack Butland says it will be a “dream come true” if he makes his senior England debut against Italy in Berne.

The 19-year-old Birmingham keeper could get the chance to feature on Wednesday after Joe Hart was ruled out with a back injury.

England boss Roy Hodgson chose not to call up a replacement for Hart, leaving Butland and John Ruddy as the only two remaining goalkeepers.

For a player whose only senior experience at domestic level are the 24 games he played on loan for Cheltenham Town, a full England game would cap a remarkable rise for Butland, who also played for Team GB during the Olympics.

Butland said: “It’s what dreams are made of. Unfortunately it’s come, or hopefully will come, due to an injury to Joe but if I get the chance it will be a dream come true.

“It’s something I can’t stop thinking about and I’d love the chance to be able to perform on that stage on Wednesday night.

“I’m not going to try and put too much pressure on myself or expect anything because there’s not a lot of goalkeepers who get the chance at such a young age. I’m very privileged to be in this position.

“I’m going to take everything in my stride. If it doesn’t happen on Wednesday I’m going to work harder to make it happen on a different occasion.”

Butland, who was part of England’s Euro 2012 Squad in Poland and Ukraine, also believes the experience of playing for Team GB at London 2012 will prove invaluable as he continues his development.

He said: “It was fantastic for everyone involved. I feel very proud and privileged that I was given a chance to be able to perform and be a part of something bigger than just football.

“You were given the chance to mix with other athletes, it was a very good experience to see how all the other sports do it and just get a feel for the Olympics. It’s something I won’t forget.”

He added: “The Euros were fantastic and it was a great experience to see and train with top players and it was a big eye-opener for me and showed me where I want to be for long periods of my career.”

Meanwhile, Manchester United midfield ace Tom Cleverley is looking to put last season’s injury woes behind him and hit the ground running as he too looks to make his England debut on Wednesday.

He said: “It was a bit of frustrating season for me.

“It always is for a footballer to be injured and not to be able to do what you do. But I’m not thinking about that now. I’m getting my head down and hoping to play as much football as possible, whether that be for England or Manchester United.”

It was initially thought Ivanovic would be unavailable to face Wigan, Reading and Newcastle after being shown a red card in the 3-2 defeat to Manchester City.

But the FA changed their rules following an incident during an Amsterdam Tournament in 2006, when Manchester United pair Paul Scholes and Wayne Rooney were both dismissed against Porto and ended up serving three-match bans.

CHELSEA captain John Terry will be free to play from the start of the Blues’ Champions League campaign after having his three-match ban reduced on appeal by UEFA.

The veteran England defender was sent off in last season’s the second leg of last season's semi-final against Barcelona in the Nou Camp for an off-the-ball clash with Alexis Sanchez.

Terry was handed an automatic three-match rap for violent conduct — the first game of which was the final against Bayern Munich, where the Roberto Di Matteo's men triumphed after a dramatic penalty shootout.

However, UEFA bigwigs have partially upheld Terry’s appeal, which means he will now also miss the Super Cup clash with Europa League winners Atletico Madrid on August 31, but with the remaining sanction suspended for three years.

A statement from UEFA said: “The UEFA Appeals Body has partially upheld Terry’s appeal against the three-match European ban imposed on the defender at the end of last season.

“Although the he is still suspended for three UEFA club competition matches, the third game of the ban has now been deferred for a probationary period of three years.

“The UEFA Appeals Body decided to partially uphold Terry’s appeal against the three-match suspension handed down to him by the UEFA Control and Disciplinary Body on 31 May.

“The England player served the first game of his European ban when he did not participate in the UEFA Champions League final against FC Bayern Munchen on May 19.

"He will also sit out Chelsea’s UEFA Super Cup match against Club Atletico Madrid on August 31.

“The original punishment related to Terry’s sending-off in the UEFA Champions League semi-final second leg at Barcelona on April 24.”

pages.headline: I won’t break
pages.teaser: THE Argy, who spent six months on strike last season, is desperate to get Manchester City off to a flying start
pages.articlebody:
GRAFTER Carlos Tevez is refusing to take a single day off in a bid to get Manchester City’s title defence off to a flying start.

Tevez spent SIX MONTHS away from Carrington last year before finally returning to help City to the title.

The Argy looked in great nick yesterday, scoring in the Premier League champions’ 3-2 win over Chelsea in the Community Shield.

And City No2 David Platt said: “Carlos has worked ever so hard in pre-season.

“Since he has come back in he has really attacked his work and not had one day off.

“His goal against Chelsea was one of those you can remember him doing two years ago.

“He ducks inside, he goes away from people. That’s what he’s been missing and it was there again.”

pages.headline: It’s a Song for Europe
pages.teaser: ALEX SONG has today confirmed Barca have been in touch with the Gunners over a £16million switch
pages.articlebody:
ALEX SONG admits he could quit Arsenal for Barcelona.

SunSport last week revealed the Catalans were weighing up a £16million swoop for the midfield ace.

And Song has today confirmed Barca have been in touch with the Gunners.

The Cameroon star insists he is “happy” in North London. But he added: “I am not going to lie if I said there is no interest.

“Barcelona are the best team in the world and speculation will always continue until the window closes.”

Meanwhile, Gunners winger Ryo Miyaichi has joined Wigan on a season-long loan.

The 19-year-old Japan international enjoyed a successful spell at Bolton towards the end of last season and will get the chance of more first-team action with the Latics.

pages.articlebody:
OLYMPIC shot put champion Nadzeya Ostapchuk has been stripped of her gold medal after failing a drugs test.

The Belarusian tested positive for the anabolic agent metenolone.

Her gold medal has been handed to Valerie Adams of New Zealand, with Russia’s Evgeniia Kolodko now taking silver and Lijiao Gong of China elevated to bronze.

pages.subdeck: THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN GLOVES ... Anthony Joshua proudly shows off his medal
pages.headline: Joshua makes it a hat-trick of boxing golds
pages.teaser: LONDONER had an anxious wait before being confirmed as the THIRD Team GB boxer to strike gold at the Olympics
pages.articlebody:
ANTHONY JOSHUA had an anxious wait before being confirmed as the THIRD member of Team GB’s boxing squad to strike gold.

Following three action-packed rounds at London’s ExCel, super-heavyweight Joshua was given the nod over Italy’s Roberto Cammarelle via countback after the judges scored the bout 18-18.

Not surprisingly, the home crowd went wild as the Londoner celebrated in the middle of the ring to round off Britain’s best performance in the sweet science at a Games since 1920.

The Italians immediately appealed the decision — leaving Londoner Joshua to discover if he had followed team-mates Nicola Adams and Luke Campbell in winning gold.

But the appeal was rejected and the 21-year-old proudly held one of his giant fists to his chest as the national anthem boomed around the arena with him on top of the podium.

A delighted Joshua said: “I pulled it out of the bag. My heart’s still pumping with adrenalin.

“I never gave up and the crowd have got behind me once again. I’m blessed.

“This medal represents my journey and the support from the team. I’m proud to have it around my neck.

“It’s not just for me, though, this is for Team GB. To the 10 of us — three girls and seven boys — this is for all of us.”

As highlighted by Joshua, Team GB’s biggest-ever squad of 10 fighters worked hand in hand to secure the impressive medal haul.

Along with the three golds, Fred Evans claimed silver and Anthony Ogogo came away with a deserved bronze.

And like his team-mates, Joshua did not have it all his own way on the road to glory.

He started brightly and the left jab which had dominated Ivan Dychko in the semi-final was once again an important factor in the final.

But if Joshua controlled the majority of the opening round, he entered dangerous territory in the last 30 seconds when he was caught in Cammarelle’s corner and tagged by four consecutive right hands.

The Brit cleared the cobwebs before starting the second session in more cautious fashion, allowing Cammarelle to dictate the pace of the contest and once again land the cleaner shots in the final moments of the round.

Going into the third and final round, Joshua was trailing 13-10.

An action-packed three minutes saw the giant Brit suddenly find success with big rights, one of which clearly rocked his opponent, and the crowd roared him through the final few seconds.

And although Italy lodged the appeal, there was never any real doubt that the right man’s hand had been raised at the end of the bout.

pages.subdeck: RIGHT ROYAL SUCCESS ... Seb Coe with the Queen at the Aquatics Centre
pages.headline: We've surpassed all hopes
pages.teaser: ORGANISER Lord Coe claims the Olympics have delivered on all promises and can inspire next GB generation of winners
pages.articlebody:
THE best part of a decade ago a small group of people got together and decided that it might be a good idea if London put in a bid to host the Olympic and Paralympic Games.

As momentum gathered, that meeting became a feasibility study, then a bid and, before we knew it, on 6 July 2005, London was awarded the honour of hosting the Games for the third time.

Then the hard work started.

The central focus of the bid was a promise to inspire young people to get involved in sport — our motto is “Inspire A Generation” — so the pressure was on.

But what we have seen over the last couple of weeks has, in my opinion, absolutely delivered on that promise.

It is easy to sound wise after the event, but I always had confidence we would.

Since winning the bid, I have spent a huge amount of time travelling the country and even before London 2012 had started, I was witnessing the power of the Games.

All over the UK, I saw young people taking up sport, inspired by the Olympic dream.

Our hope was that the Games would turbo-charge this enthusiasm and provide a once-in-a-generation opportunity to make a real difference.

But what we have seen this summer has surpassed everyone’s expectations.

There have been some magical performances from our athletes, which are going to live long in the memory of all the generations.

The way the whole country has got behind the Games has been a source of immense pride.

The British supporters packing our venues created a magical atmosphere for the athletes.

Our volunteers have been complete stars — the face of our Games — welcoming visitors with a smile and sending them on their way with a smile.

Our Games-makers have the right to say: “I made London 2012.” They did.

But what now? In terms of delivering world-class events, Britain is at the top of its game right now, so capitalising on this within the UK and around the world is clearly a priority.

Plans are already in place with the Government to help take advantage of this moment and to ensure this opportunity is not lost.

We are already seeing many UK businesses who worked on the Games picking up contracts with other major events.

You can do your bit too. If your kids were inspired by Mo Farah, Laura Trott or Ben Ainslie, find a local club, enrol your child and enrol yourself to be a volunteer.

One of the enduring impressions of these Games was the immense pride felt by the families and friends of athletes who competed.

I said in my speech at the Opening Ceremony that “one day we will tell our children and our grandchildren that when our time came we did it right”.

We did it right, so thank you to every Sun reader who came to our Games, every Sun reader who volunteered, who watched and cheered as Team GB brought home medal after medal.

These Games brought out the best in us and will help define us on a global scale.

But, of course, our job is only half done. In a couple of weeks’ time we host the world’s second biggest multi-sport event — the Paralympic Games.

This is another opportunity to inspire a generation and shine a light on more inspirational sport.

Believe me, these are athletes who will make you sit up and take notice.

And once again, I am sure with The Sun’s support, Team GB will shine.

pages.subdeck: TRIBUTE ... Usain Bolt does the Mobot
pages.headline: Mobot was no Bolt from blue
pages.teaser: USAIN BOLT admitted he planned to do Mo Farah’s ‘Mobot’ celebration before London 2012 even began
pages.articlebody:
USAIN BOLT admitted he planned to do Mo Farah’s ‘Mobot’ celebration before London 2012 even began.

Bolt celebrated with pal Farah after the Brit won 5000 metres gold on Saturday to complete the track’s long distance double.

Sprint legend Bolt went on to win 4x100m gold with the Jamaican team, smashing their own world record.

He said: “Before the Olympics I said ‘I’m going to do the Mobot but then I forgot when I won 100m and 200m golds.

“But before I came out for the 4x100m I watched Mo in his 5000m final and made sure I remembered to do it. It was fun.

“Mo and I go way back. We’ve both been through ups and downs so it was a joy for me to see him get the double gold. It was wonderful.”

Bolt, meanwhile, is in talks over a shock appearance in Twenty20 cricket.

He has spoken to Australia spin legend Shane Warne about playing for Melbourne Stars in the Australian Big Bash League.

Bolt said: “If I get the chance I will definitely give it a go.”

pages.subdeck: YOU ARE GOLD ... Mo Farah with both his gold medals from the 10,000m and 5,000m
pages.headline: Streets of London will be paved with Mo’s gold
pages.teaser: DOUBLE medal hero wants to run the London Marathon now he has won the Olympic distance double in home city
pages.articlebody:
MO FARAH wants to run the London Marathon now he has won the Olympic distance double in his home city.

And despite becoming the first Brit to achieve that double at the same Games, he insists he still has a long way to go to be a true great of the track similar to athletes such as Seb Coe and Steve Ovett.

Seven days after making himself the first British male to win an Olympic distance title with his 10,000m gold, on Saturday he pulled off one of the greatest feats athletics in this country has ever seen — also winning 5,000m gold with a SPRINT finish.

Over the past 40 years, only three men have ever achieved the double at the same Olympics — Lasse Viren in 1972 and 1976, Miruts Yifter in 1980 and Kenenisa Bekele, who Farah beat to take 10,000m gold, in Beijing four years ago.

Now Farah, 29, admits that after experiencing the 80,000-crowd roaring him on at the Olympic Stadium, he would love to run along the streets of London in front of thousands more.

Stepping up to the 26.2mile event — as former Olympic 10,000m champion Haile Gebreselassie did — is something his mentor and former London Marathon chief executive Dave Bedford has talked of for some time.

Farah, who will compete over two miles at the Birmingham Grand Prix on August 26 and in the Great North Run next month, declared: “I’m not sure about next year but I do want to run the London Marathon.

“I am quite excited about it and the crowd certainly would be amazing. It’s an option, though I have not yet talked to my coach Alberto Salazar about it.

“I think Alberto will probably say it’s too early for the road, keep to the track. But if I feel I am losing my speed on the track, I will go in that direction.

“Things are going well and as an athlete you want to be able to collect as many medals throughout your career as you can. So I want to keep going now. Championships don’t come around that often.”

Farah has huge admiration for Salazar, though the Cuban-born former athlete, famed for winning the three successive New York Marathons in the 80s, came in for criticism when Farah failed to win a medal at the World Indoors in Istanbul in March.

Yet the 54-year-old’s methods ultimately worked to perfection, with Farah able to run the last lap of each London victory in 53 seconds to repel the chasing pack.

Farah stated: “Alberto is a genius. That last lap has been the difference, One or two per cent.

“I’ve always had it but I just haven’t been able to finish races. Now I am finishing races strongly.

“They were queuing up to pass me and I could feel that but I was not going to let anyone past me. It’s an incredible feeling.”

Yesterday London 2012 chairman Seb Coe, who with arch-rival Ovett dominated the 800m and 1500m in the 1980s, claimed Farah was Britain’s greatest-ever runner.

But Farah added: “No way. Athletes like Coe and Ovett won medals and broke records all the time.

“I just leave it to the public to judge things like that and get on with my running.

“Usain Bolt had to defend both his Olympic titles to be a legend. But I can play around with different events, so it’s hard to compare.

“To be a legend like him you have to go from track to world records and the marathon. There is lots to be done. I don’t consider myself a legend or anything like it.

“A couple of years ago, Gebrselassie gave me no chance of ever winning a global title.

“So it’s unbelievable how things turn around.

“I always believe in myself. But, to be honest, not enough to think I would be a double Olympic champion. Yet once you win one gold, you want to win more.

“Running in the 5,000m, I put the 10,000m gold to the back of my mind. I was thinking I have to win this, I want that medal."
